SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (3rd shift) (a) Bharathapuzha (b) Periyar (c) Pamba (d) Penner Sol.178.(d) P enner - It rises in Nandi Hills in Chikballapur District of Karnataka and falls into the Bay of Bengal. Bhar athapuzha (P onnani) river is Kerala's second longest West Flowing River, draining into the Arabian Sea. Q.179 . A long, winding ridge of strati ﬁ ed sand and gravel is known as: Graduate Level 27/06/2023 ( Shift - 4) (a) whorl (b) esker (c) lop (d) arch Sol.179.(b) Esk er . These are ridges made of sands and gravels, deposited by glacial meltwater ﬂowing through tunnels within and underneath glaciers, or through meltwater channels on top of glaciers. Other depositional landforms: Drumlins are smooth oval shaped ridge -like features composed mainly of glacial till with some masses of gravel and sand.

questions.question: Which is a saltwater lake located in the Tibet Autonomous Region, China, to the west of Lake Mansarovar and to the south of Mount Kailash?
questions.explanation: Lak e Rakshastal. Pangong Lake - World's highest saltwater lake. Loktak Lake (Floating lake, Manipur) is famous for phumdi and Keibul Lamjao National Park is the only ﬂoating national park in the world located on it. RanwuLake (Rawok-Tso) - Largest lake of Eastern Tibet (Pasho). Yamdrok Lake (Freshwater lake inTibet).

questions.question: The Almatti Dam of Karnataka is built over which of the following rivers?
questions.explanation: Krishna. Other dams on Krishna river - Achakdani (Maharashtra), Achler (Maharashtra). River (Dams) : Kaveri {Alalur (Karnataka), Amaravathi, (Tamil Nadu)}, Periyar {Mullaperiyar (Kerala)}.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding large dams? I. They have social problems because they displace a large number of peasants and tribals without adequate compensation or rehabilitation. Il. They have Environmental problems because they contribute enormously to deforestation and the loss of biological diversity.
questions.explanation: Both I and II. Adv antages of Dams - Irrigation, tourist attraction, ﬂood contr ol, hydro power generation, etc. Disadv antages of dams - High construction cost, unbalanced sedimentation, deforestation, ecological imbalance, endangered aquatic life etc.

questions.question: Which of the following rivers originates in Rajasthan?
questions.explanation: Banas . The river originates from the Khamnor hills of the Aravali range. It is a tributary of the Chambal River. It is also known as “Van ki Asha”. Length of Banas: 512 km. T ributaries : Kothari, Dai, Dheel, Menali etc.

questions.question: Jabalpur is located on the banks of which of the following rivers?
questions.explanation: Narmada (Reva River, 1312 km): India’s 5th longest and largest west- ﬂ owing river, running through a rift valley between the Vindhya and Satpura ranges.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an important river of Malwa plateau?
questions.explanation: Mahanadi. Rivers of Malwa plateau - Mahi River, Ken river, Shipra River, Chambal River, Betwa River.

questions.question: Kadana Dam of Gujarat is built over which of the following rivers?
questions.explanation: Mahi Riv er . Indian Rivers and Dams: Sabarmati River - Dharoi Dam (Gujarat). Tapti River - Hatnur Dam (Maharashtra), Ukai Dam (Gujarat), Girna Dam (Maharashtra), Dahigam Weir (Maharashtra). Krishna River - Nagarjuna sagar Dam (Telangana). Manjira River - Singur Dam and Nizam Sagar dam (Telangana). Banas River - Bisalpur Dam (Rajasthan).

questions.question: Which of the following rivers forms the Dhuandhar falls?
questions.explanation: Narmada. The Dhuandhar Falls is located in the Jabalpur district of Madhya Pradesh.

questions.question: Which among the following lakes connects the twin cities of Hyderabad and Secunderabad?
questions.explanation: Hussain Sagar: A heart - shaped lake in Hyderabad, Telangana, built by Ibrahim Quli Qutb Shah; Fed by the River Musi. Salim Ali lake - Aurangabad, Kanwar lake - Bihar, Periyar lake - Kerala.

questions.question: The region of Ganga Brahmaputra basin lies in____.
questions.explanation: 10°N t o 30°N latitude. The Brahmaputra originates in the north of the Himalayas near Mansarovar Lake in the Purang district of Tibet (Known as Yarlung Tsangpo in Tibet), (other names : Siang/Dihang River) India, and Bangladesh (Jamuna River). The Delta formed by Ganga Brahmaputra is Sunderban Delta (largest delta in the world).

questions.question: In which state of India is Tawa dam located?
questions.explanation: Madhy a Pr adesh - Indra Sagar dam, largest in state (Narmada river), Gandhisagar Dam (Chambal River), Bargi Dam (Narmada River). Uttar Pradesh - Rihand dam also known as Govind Ballabh Pant Sagar. Haryana - Kaushalya Dam (Yamuna River), Anangpur Dam (Hakra River). Gujarat - Sardar Sarovar Dam (Narmada River). Rajasthan - Rana Pratap Sagar (Chambal river).

questions.question: Arrange the following rivers as they occur in the North-South direction in India. Beas, Indus, Chenab, Satluj, Ravi
questions.explanation: Indus (Sindhu) river - Source (Lake Manasarovar), Satluj (Lake Rakshastal in Tibet), Ravi (Multhan tehsil of Kangra district of Himachal Pradesh), Chenab (Baralacha Pass in Himachal Pradesh) etc.

questions.question: Which is a major watershed for the headwaters of the Yamuna River lies in the western Garhwal region of Uttarakhand?
questions.explanation: Bandarpunch glacier (part of Sankari range and lies within the Govind Pashu Vihar National park and Sanctuary). Dokriani glacier {located in the Bhagirathi basin of the central Himalaya, Uttarkashi district (Uttrakhand)}. Kafni Glacier {located in the upper reaches of the Kumaon Himalayas, to the southeast of Nanda Devi, gives rise to the Kafni River (tributary of the Pindar River)}. Doonagiri Glacier {Garhwal Himalayas, Dhauli ganga system of Glaciers}.

questions.question: In which state of India is the Kangra and Kullu valley located?
questions.explanation: Himachal Pr adesh. Kangr a Valley (river valley situated in theWestern Himalayas), Kullu Valley (formed by the Beas River between Manali and Larji). Other famous valleys in Himachal Pradesh: Solang Valley, Spiti Valley, Tirthan Valley, Kinnaur valley, Green Valley, Barot Valley, Lahaul Valley, Pabbar Valley, etc.

questions.question: Which state in India is the source of river Ghaggar?
questions.explanation: Himachal Pr adesh (Shivalik hills). It ﬂows through Punjab, Haryana and then into Rajasthan. It ﬂows only during the monsoon season. It is known as Hakra river in Pakistan. The main tributaries of the Ghaggar are the Kaushalya river, Markanda, Sarsuti, Tangri and Chautang.

questions.question: India and Sri Lanka are joined by a group of islets forming ______.
questions.explanation: Adam ' s Bridge (Rama Setu), is a chain of limestone shoals, between Pamban Island (Rameswaram Island), Tamil Nadu, India, and Mannar Island, Sri Lanka. Mahatma Gandhi Setu (Bihar), Sisseri River Bridge (Arunachal Pradesh), Bhupen Hazarika bridge (Connects Assam and Arunachal Pradesh).

questions.question: Pushkar lake is situated in which district of Rajasthan?
questions.explanation: Ajmer . F r eshwater Lak es in Rajasthan: Ajmer - Ana Sagar Lake, Lake Foy Sagar; Alwar - Siliserh Lake; Banswara - Anand Sagar Lake and Dailab Lake; Bundi - Jait Sagar Lake, Kanak Sagar Lake, and Nawar Sagar Lake; Dungarpur - Gaib Sagar Lake; Jaisalmer - Gadsisar Lake; Jodhpur - Balsamand Lake, Kailana Lake; Kota - Kishore Sagar Lake; Rajsamand - Rajsamand Lake; Udaipur - Doodh Talai, Fateh Sagar Lake, Jaisamand Lake, Udai Sagar Lake, and Pichola Lake.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the term Moraine?

options.b: Material transported and deposited by glacier
options.c: Valley with vertical sides and wideﬂoor

questions.explanation: A moraine is material left behind by a moving glacier. This material is usually soil and rock. Moraines are divided into four main categories: lateral moraines, medial moraines, supraglacial moraines, and terminal moraines.

questions.question: Which of the following ports is known as ‘Diamond Harbour’?
questions.explanation: K olkata Port (Haldia seaport) is the only riverine Major Port situated on the Hugli river in West Bengal. Cochin Port or Kochi port lies on two islands in the Vembanadu Lake; Willingdon Island and Vallarpadam and is important for the export of spices and salt.

questions.question: Which lake of India is the result of tectonic activity?
questions.explanation: W ular Lak e, one of Asia's largest freshwater lakes, is fed by the Jhelum River and located in Bandipora, Jammu and Kashmir. Barapani lake located in Meghalaya.

questions.question: Tsomgo Lake is a glacial lake located in which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Sikkim. T songmo Lak e (Changu Lake) remains frozen during the winter season. It is revered as a holy lake by the people of Sikkim.

questions.question: The Ganga plain extends between two rivers?
questions.explanation: Ghaggar and T eesta. Six Physiogr aphic Divisions of India - 1. The Himalayan Mountains 2. The Northern Plains 3. The Peninsular Plateau 4. The Indian Desert 5. The Coastal Plains 6. The Islands. The Western part of the Northern Plain is referred to as the Punjab Plains. Brahmaputra plain lies in the state of Assam.

questions.question: Which river basin covers an area of 65,145 , of which about 80% lies in 𝑘𝑚2 Maharashtra?
questions.explanation: T api Basin is situated in the northern part of the Deccan Plateau. Nearly 80% of the basin lies in the State of Maharashtra.

questions.question: Which state does the Brahmaputra river enter when it takes a U turn at Namcha Barwa?
questions.explanation: Arunachal Pr adesh. The catchment area of the Brahmaputra (Tsangpo) river falls in four countries (Tibet, Bhutan, India, and Bangladesh).

questions.question: Which river basin covers an area of 8,60,000 and is spread across 11 𝑘𝑚2 Indian states?
questions.explanation: Ganga Basin - 11 States. Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Bihar, Jharkhand, Rajasthan, West Bengal, Haryana, Himachal Pradesh and Delhi. Indus Basin - Himachal Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan and Jammu & Kashmir. Br ahmaputr a Basin - Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, West Bengal, Meghalaya, Nagaland, Sikkim.

questions.question: Which river rises near Mhow in the Malwa plateau of Madhya Pradesh?
questions.explanation: Chambal. V aruna River (Tributary of Ganga River originates in Phulpur in the Prayagraj district). Betwa Riv er (originates from Hoshangabad, Vindhya Range, Madhya Pradesh.

questions.question: In ancient times, which river was also known as 'Pooni' in Tamil which is the fourth largest river ﬂowing in the southeast direction through the states of Karnataka and Tamil Nadu ?
questions.explanation: Ka v eri Riv er . It is a sacred river in southern India. It rises on Brahmagiri Hill of the Western Ghats in southwestern Karnataka state and drains into the Bay of Bengal throughPondicherry.

questions.question: The Hundru Fall lies along the course of which of the following rivers?
questions.explanation: Subarnar ekha. It is located in Ranchi District. Rajrappa waterfalls occur at the con ﬂ uence of River Bhairavi and river Damodar.

questions.question: River Ken is one of the major rivers of the Bundelkhand region of central India and ﬂows through two states, Madhya Pradesh and ______.
questions.explanation: Uttar Pr adesh. River Ken It is a tributary of the Yamuna. The impor tant tributaries of K en - Alona, Bearma, Sonar, Mirhasan, Shyamari, Banne, Kutri, Urmil, Kail and Chandrawal.

questions.question: Which of the following rivers form Kunchikal waterfall in Karnataka?
questions.explanation: V ar ahi. Kunchikal Falls is located in Nidagodu village near Masthikatte in Shimoga district of state Karnataka. It cascades down rocky boulders and the total height of fall is 455 meters.

questions.question: The river Indus was called ______ by the Iranians and the Greeks about 2500 years ago.
questions.explanation: Hindos. This word is derived from the Sanskrit word "Sindhu'', which means "river".

questions.question: On which of the following rivers is Pakistan constructing a dam named Diamer Basha' dam?
questions.explanation: Indus. It is located between Kohistan district in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Diamer district in Gilgit Baltistan, Pakistan administered Kashmir.

questions.question: Which of the following waterfalls is in the state of Goa?
questions.explanation: Dudhsagar F alls is a four-tiered waterfall on the Mandovi River. Duduma Falls lies on the border of Koraput (Odisha) and Visakhapatnam (Andhra Pradesh). Gokak Falls is on the Ghataprabha River in Belagavi, Karnataka. Shivasamudram Falls is located in Chamarajanagar and Mandya districts, Karnataka.

questions.question: Which of the following is the largest west ﬂowing river in Rajasthan?
questions.explanation: L uni River originates in the Pushkar valley, Aravalli Range, ﬂows thr ough the Thar Desert, and ends in the Rann of Kutch, Gujarat.

questions.question: In which of the following states is the Bhambavli Vajrai Waterfall located?
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a. This waterfall is situated in the district of Satara in western Maharashtra. F amous water falls in Mahar ashtr a - Malshej Falls, Pandavkada waterfall, Randha Falls, Chinaman's Falls, Dhobi Waterfall, Sahastrakund waterfalls, Zenith Falls, Vihigaon Waterfall.

questions.question: Which of the following states has the largest catchment area of Godavari Basin?
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a. Banganga, Kadva, Shivana, Purna, Kadam, Pranahita, Indravati, Taliperu, Sabari, Nasardi, Pravara, Sindphana, Manjira, Manair, Kinnerasani are tributaries of Godavari river.

questions.question: In which Indian state will you ﬁnd the river Muhuri?
questions.explanation: T ripur a. Muhuri is a transnational river between India and Bangladesh. Rising in Tripura, It ﬂows int o Bangladesh where it merges with the Feni near the latter's mouth to the Bay of Bengal.

questions.question: In which Indian state is the 'Bhushi Lake' located?
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a. P opular Lak es in Mahar ashtr a - Upvan Lake, Vihar Lake, Powai Lake, Rankala Lake, Panshet Lake, Ganesh Lake, Venna Lake, Lonar Lake.

questions.question: Which Indian state is the source of the rivers Brahmani, Kharkai and Subarnarekha?
questions.explanation: Jharkhand. Other rivers in Jharkhand - Sone, Barakar, Damodar, Ajay, South Koel, Shankh, and North Koel river.

questions.question: Gurdwara Patalpuri Sahib is located on the bank of river ______.
questions.explanation: Sutlej. Gurdwara Patalpuri Sahib located in Rupnagar district of Punjab. Guru Hargobind Ji in 1644 as well as Guru Har Rai Ji in 1661 were cremated here.

questions.question: Which of the following is a tributary of the river Brahmaputra that ﬂows through Bhutan?
questions.explanation: W ang Chhu Riv er . Bhutan has four major rivers, named Drangme Chhu, Mo Chhu, Wang Chhu and Torsa Chhu. The Brahmaputra is one of the largest rivers of the Indian Subcontinent.

questions.question: In which of the following states is Anchar Lake located?
questions.explanation: Jammu and Kashmir . It is located near the Soura area in the city of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir. The lake is connected with the famous Dal Lake.

questions.question: Yerla, Warna and Dindi are tributaries of the ______ river system.
questions.explanation: Krishna.

questions.question: A/an __________ is a natural geo - hydrological unit of land, which collects water and drains it through a common point by a system of streams.
questions.explanation: W atershed. Types (In hectare) : Macro watershed (> 50,000), Sub-watershed (10,000 to 50,000), Milli-watershed (1000 to 10000), Micro watershed (100 to 1000), Mini watershed (1-100).

questions.question: A channel of a canal where water ﬂows under the inﬂ uence of gravity is called ______.
questions.explanation: ﬂ ow channel. It is the ﬂow of water induced by the effect of gravity. The surface of the ﬂowing liquid is at atmospheric pressure and free to air. The example of open channel ﬂow includes ﬂow in canal, river, etc.

questions.question: On which river is Peacock Island located?
questions.explanation: Br ahmaputr a. Peacock Island or Umananda Island is the smallest inhabited river island in the middle of river Brahmaputra, ﬂowing thr ough the city of Guwahati. Its name derives from Assamese Uma. It is also known as Bhasmachal.

questions.question: Which of the following is Uttarakhand’s ﬁrst gravity dam?
questions.explanation: Song dam which is to be built on the foothills of Mussoorie on the Song river to meet the water shortage of the state during the summers.

questions.question: Which one of the following is the longest river of Nepal ?
questions.explanation: Riv er Karnali also called Ghaghara is a perennial transboundary river originating on the Tibetan Plateau near Lake Manasarovar.

questions.question: Which type of dam is a temporary dam constructed to exclude water from the speci ﬁ c area?
questions.explanation: coff er . It is built to permitdamming, diversion, or dewatering and construction of a permanent structure in a dry area. A detention dam is built to catch surface runoff and stream water ﬂow to regulate the water ﬂow in areas below the dam. Detention dams are commonly used to reduce the damage caused by ﬂooding or to manage the ﬂow r ate through a channel.

questions.question: Suryadhar lake is located in which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Uttar akhand. Famous Lakes in Uttarakhand - Auli Arti ﬁ cial Lake, Baraadsar Lake, Bedni Kund , Bhalu Dam, Bhimtal Lake, Bhulla Tal, Bisurital, Brahmatal Trek etc.

questions.question: In which of the following states is the Sirki Waterfall located?
questions.explanation: Arunachal Pr adesh. Other Waterfalls - The Nuranang Waterfall, the Bap Teng Kang Waterfall.

questions.question: Which river has the tributaries by the name of Mayurakshi, Damodar, Kangsabati and Rupnarayan ?
questions.explanation: Hooghly. It is the eastern distributary of the Ganges River in West Bengal.

questions.question: Chulia waterfall is situated on Chambal River in ______.
questions.explanation: Rajasthan. State and Waterfall : Uttar Pradesh - Lakhaniya Dari Falls; Gujarat - Shankar Waterfall; Madhya Pradesh - Dhuandhar Falls.

questions.question: Rain is liquid ______.
questions.explanation: Pr ecipitation is any product of the condensation of atmospheric water vapor that falls under gravitational pull from clouds. The main forms of precipitation include drizzling, rain, sleet, snow, ice pellets, graupel and hail.

questions.question: Which of the following dams is located in Jharkhand?
questions.explanation: Maithon dam is on the river Barakar in the district Dhanbad of Jharkhand. It has an underground power station, the ﬁrst of its own kind in the whole of SouthEast Asia.

questions.question: The mouth of which of the following rivers lies to the north of the Tropic of Cancer ?
questions.explanation: Indus. Mahanadi, Krishna and Kaveri are all rivers of the South so they lie to the south of tropic of cancer.

questions.question: What kind of depositional landforms are formed when streams ﬂowing from higher levels break into foot slope plains of low gradient?
questions.explanation: Alluvial fans. A point bar is a depositional feature made of alluvium that accumulates on the inside bend of streams and rivers below the slip-off slope. An alluvial fan is a triangle-shaped deposit of gravel, sand, and even smaller pieces of sediment, such as silt.

questions.question: Where is the Baglihar Dam located?
questions.explanation: Jammu and Kashmir . Baglihar dam is a run-of-the-river power project on the Chenab river. Important Dams - Kadana Dam (Gujarat), Chamera Dam (Himachal Pradesh), Singur Dam (Telangana).

questions.question: A river is capable of forming which of the following landscapes when the river is in its middle course?
questions.explanation: A meander is a U-shaped bend in a river formed by erosion and deposition. A V-shaped valley is createdby river erosion. A waterfall is where water drops vertically over a ledge. A delta forms at a river's mouth where it meets the sea or ocean.

questions.question: Which of the following has the highest salinity?
questions.explanation: Lak e V an. Being the largest lake in Turkey, it has the highest salinity (330%). As a saline soda lake fed by small streams, it is one of the few endorheic lakes over 3,000 square kilometers. High salinity usually prevents it from freezing, despite high altitude and winter temperatures below 0 °C (32 °F).

questions.question: As of 2021, which is the world's largest drainage basin with an area of about 70,00,000 km2?
questions.explanation: A maz on basin. The Amazon Basin, formed by numerous tributaries, drains parts of Brazil, Peru, Bolivia, Ecuador, Colombia, and a small section of Venezuela. It lies directly on the equator and experiences a hot, humid climate year-round, with both day and night feeling equally warm and sticky. High rainfall, high temperature, and high humidity are the features of the basin.

questions.question: Which of the following is the largest arti ﬁ cial lake of Asia?
questions.explanation: Bhopal Lak e, also known as Bhojtal, was created in the 11th century by King Bhoja of the Paramara dynasty. It is situated in Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, and is constructed on Kolans river. Lakes in Madhya Pradesh: Sangram Sagar, Shahpura lake. Dal Lake - It is often referred to as Srinagar's Jewel, is a freshwater lake located in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

questions.question: Which river originates south of the equator and ﬂows north through north-eastern Africa to drain into the Mediterranean Sea?
questions.explanation: Nile Riv er . Its length is about 6,695 kilometers (4,160 miles). The Nile basin is huge and includes parts ofTanzania, Burundi, Rwanda, Congo (Kinshasa), Kenya. Other important rivers of the world : Lena River : Origin - Baikal range, Drains - Laptev Sea. Amazon River : Origin - Andes Mountains, Drains - Atlantic Ocean. Congo River (cross the equator twice) : Origin - Africa Rift, Drains - Atlantic Ocean.

questions.question: Where are Huka Falls located ?
questions.explanation: New Z ealand. Huka Falls is on the Waikato River. Major Waterfalls: New Zealand - Kitekite Falls, Dawson Falls, Taranaki Falls, Owharoa Falls. Germany - Triberger Waterfall, Todtnau falls. Spa. Australia - Wallaman Falls, Millaain - Salto del Nervion, Fervenza do Ezaro Millaa falls, Liffey Falls, Russell Falls. Angel Falls in Venezuela is the highest waterfall in the world.

questions.question: Where is Red Lake found ?
questions.explanation: USA. Country and Lakes: USA - Abert, Ontario, Erie, Huron, Michigan. India - Chilka Lake, Sambhar Salt Lake, Loktak Lake, Wular Lake. Canada - Aberdeen Lake, Lake Abitibi. Brazil - Agua Vermelha. Australia - Lake Alexandrina, Lake Amadeus. Scotland - Loch Lomond.

questions.question: Which of the following is the highest navigable lake in the world?
questions.explanation: Titicaca - Situated 3810 m above sea level and is situated between Peru to the west and Bolivia to the east, South America.

questions.question: Which is the correct sequence of lakes according to depth (from maximum to minimum) ?
questions.explanation: Baikal (world’s deepest lake): Depth - 5,387 ft, Location - Russia. Tanganyika: Depth - 4,823 ft, Location - Central Africa on the borders of Tanzania, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Zambia and Burundi. Caspian Sea: Depth - 3,363 ft, Location - Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Iran, Azerbaijan, and Russia. Vostok: Depth - about 3000 ft, Location - Antarctica.

questions.question: What is the total number of rivers including tributaries in Bangladesh?
questions.explanation: About 700. Bangladesh : It has four major river systems – The Brahmaputra - Jamuna, the Ganges - Padma, the Surma - Meghna and the Chittagong region river system. Chittagong is the largest and most important seaport in Bangladesh.

questions.question: Which sea, located in the north -western part of the Indian Ocean, joins the Gulf of Oman in the north-west and the Gulf of Aden in the south-west and covers a total area of 1,491,000 square miles?
questions.explanation: Ar abian Sea forms part of the sea route between Europe and India. Name of Straits and Joining Seas - Strait of Gibraltar (Atlantic Ocean with the Mediterranean Sea), Sunda Strait (Java Sea and Indian Ocean), Mesina Strait ( island of Sicily and the southern tip of mainland Italy), Bab-el-Mandeb Strait (Red Sea and Gulf of Aden), North Channel (Irish Sea and Atlantic Ocean).

questions.question: Which of the following channels or straits is located between the Great Nicobar Island and Indonesia's Sumatra Island?
questions.explanation: Gr and Channel. The Coco Strait is between the North Andaman islands and the Coco Islands of Myanmar. Sumatra and Java are separated by the Sunda Strait.

questions.question: The city of _________ is located at the mouth of the Yangtze River.
questions.explanation: Shanghai. Yangtze river (approximately 6300 km) is the longestriver of both China and Asia. It rises in the mountains of Qinghai province of China.

topic: Minerals and Energy Resources in India

questions.question: Which of the following river valleys is NOT known for coal deposits in India ?
questions.explanation: Satluj. The Satluj originates in the 'Raksas tal' near Mansarovar at an altitude of 4,555 m in Tibet where it is known as Langchen Khambab. Satluj, is the longest of the ﬁv e rivers that ﬂow thr ough the historic crossroads region of Punjab in northern India and Pakistan. The Damodar Valley is particularly rich in coal and is known as the "Ruhr of India" because of its similarities to the coal-rich Ruhr region of Germany.

questions.question: Which of the following is a precious mineral?
questions.explanation: Platinum. It is used in hard disk drives, thermocouples, optical ﬁbers, L CDs, turbine blades, and spark plugs. Hematite: A common iron ore used in iron production. Platinum-based drugs cisplatin, carboplatin, and oxaliplatin are widely used for chemotherapeutic eradication of cancer. Mica: A group of silicate minerals used in various industrial applications, including electronics and construction. Bauxite: The primary ore of aluminum.

questions.question: The Panchpatmali mineral deposit region is located in which state from the following?
questions.explanation: Odisha. Panchpatmali deposits in Koraput district are the most important bauxite deposits in the state. Important Mines deposit in India: Balaghat mines (Madhya Pradesh), Khetri mines (Rajasthan), Maikal hills (Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh), Nellore mica belt (Andhra Pradesh), Kudremukh mines (Karnataka).

questions.question: Which type of coal is found in Damodar valley?
questions.explanation: Bituminous is a type of coal with a carbon content ranging from 60% to 80% and a relatively low moisture content, making it highly e ﬃ cient for energy production. It has a high calori ﬁ c value. The Damodar Valley, located in the states of Jharkhand and West Bengal in eastern India, is renowned for its extensive bituminous coal deposits. This region is part of the Jharia and Raniganj coal ﬁ elds, which are signiﬁ cant contributors to India's coal production.

questions.question: Which of the following is an inosilicate amphibole mineral used in highway construction and as railroad ballast?
questions.explanation: Hornblende: It is an inosilicate amphibole mineral. Uses: Highway construction: As an aggregate for road bases and surfaces. Railroad ballast: To provide drainage and stability under railroad tracks.

questions.question: Which coal is low-grade, brown and soft with high moisture content?
questions.explanation: Lignite . Bituminous: Medium-grade, black, and less moisture content than lignite, used for electricity, industrial, and domestic purposes. Anthracite: High-grade, hard, black, and very low moisture content, used for residential heating and industrial processes. Tamil Nadu is the largest producer of lignite in India.

questions.question: Match the following renewable sources of energy with their producing regions in India correctly.Renewable source of energyRegions in India 1. Tidal energy a. Gulf of Khambhat 2. Wind energy b. Nagercoil 3. Geo Thermal energyc. Puga valley
questions.explanation: 1-a, 2-b, 3-c. Renewable energy comes from natural sources that are regenerated more quickly than they are used up. They are natural and self-replenishing, and usually have a low- or zero-carbon footprint. Examples of renewable energy sources include wind power, solar power, bioenergy (organic matter burned as a fuel) and hydroelectric.

questions.question: The district of Shivamogga that is famous for its Iron-Ore and Manganese mineral is located in which state of India?
questions.explanation: Karnataka. Other famous mines in India: Panna and Bunder Project - Madhya Pradesh. West Singhbhum, Pahadia, Kunderkocha and Parasi - Jharkhand. Bailadila iron ore and Dalli-Rajhara - Chhattisgarh. Ratnagiri - Maharashtra. Sundergarh, Joda, Keonjhar and Jajpur - Odisha.

questions.question: Where is the Narora Nuclear Power plant located?
questions.explanation: Uttar Pr adesh. Operational Nuclear power plants in India: Kakrapar Atomic Power Station (Gujarat), Madras Atomic Power Station (Tamil Nadu), Kaiga Nuclear Power Plant (Karnataka), Rajasthan Atomic Power Station (Rajasthan), Tarapur Atomic Power Station (Maharashtra), Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant (Tamil Nadu).

questions.question: The Mundra Thermal Power Plant is located in which district of Gujarat?
questions.explanation: K utch. The Mundra Thermal Power Plant in Gujarat. Other Power plants in Gujarat: Jhanor-Gandhar Thermal Power Station, Kawas Thermal Power Station, Essar Power Gujarat Limited, Kutch Lignite Thermal Power Station, Sabarmati Thermal Power Station, Sikka Thermal Power Station, Surat Lignite Thermal Power Station, Ukai Thermal Power Station, Wanakbori Thermal Power Station.

questions.question: Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh states are rich with ____________ material deposits.
questions.explanation: Coal. Jharkhand - 40% of the country's total mineral resources are available here. It produces coking coal,uranium, and pyrite. Jharkhand ranks 1st in the production of coal, mica, kyanite, and copper in India. Major coal ﬁelds include Jharia, Bokaro, Karanpura, Hutar, Auranga, Daltonganj, Deoghar, and Rajmahal. Chhattisgarh: A leading producer of coal, dolomite, bauxite, and iron ore. Major coal-producing areas include Korea, Korba, Raigarh, and Sarguja districts.

questions.question: The Salal Project, also called the Salal Hydroelectric Power Station, is on which river?
questions.explanation: Chenab. Salal Hydroelectric Power Station is a run-of-the-river power project in the Reasi district of Jammu and Kashmir. The project has a capacity of 690 MW. The bene ﬁ ciary states are Uttar Pradesh, Jammu and Kashmir, Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Himachal Pradesh, Chandigarh & Rajasthan. Important hydel power stations and the rivers on which they are located: Bhakra Nangal (Sutlej River), Gandhi Sagar Dam (Chambal River), and Nagarjuna Sagar Dam (Krishna River).

questions.question: Identify a conventional source of energy from the following options.
questions.explanation: Cattle dung. Mineral fuels like coal, petroleum and natural gas (known as fossil fuels), nuclear energy minerals, are the conventional sources of energy. These conventional sources are exhaustible resources.

questions.question: The Durg-Bastar-Chandrapur iron ore belt lies in _____ states.
questions.explanation: Chhattisgarh and Mahar ashtr a. The Durg-Bastar-Chandrapur iron ore belt stretches across the Durg and Bastar districts in Chhattisgarh and the Chandrapur district in Maharashtra. Iron ore mines in India: Bailadila (Chhattisgarh), Joda (Odisha), Noamundi (Jharkhand), and Kudremukh (Karnataka).

questions.question: Which of the following agencies is responsible for the operation and maintenance of the Hazira- Vijaypur- Jagdishpur pipeline?
questions.explanation: Hazira-Vijaipur-Jagdishpur (HVJ) is India's ﬁrst cross-country natural gas pipeline commissioned in 1987-88 with compressor stations at Hazira, Jhabua (Madhya Pradesh), Vijaipur (Madhya Pradesh) and Auraiya (Uttar Pradesh). It transports natural gas from Hazira in Gujarat to Jagdishpur in Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: According to the Indian Mineral Yearbook 2018, which state alone accounts for 72% of the magnetite deposits in India?
questions.explanation: Karnataka is the leading producer of iron ore in India, with major deposits located in the Bellary-Hospet, Chitradurga, and Shimoga regions. Other signi ﬁ cant iron ore-producing states include Odisha, Jharkhand, and Chhattisgarh.

questions.question: NALCO is an Indian government enterprise, dealing with which of the following minerals?
questions.explanation: Bauxite. National Aluminium Company Limited (NALCO), a ‘Navratna’ public sector undertaking (PSU) established in 1981. Headquarters - Bhubaneswar, Odisha. Odisha has the largest bauxite reserves in India. Lohardaga in Jharkhand is known as the land of bauxite mines.

questions.question: Which of the following are major coal ﬁelds in India?
questions.explanation: Jharia and Raniganj. Jharkhand is home to several signi ﬁ cant coal ﬁ elds, including Jharia (the largest), Bokaro, Dhanbad, Giridih, Karanpura, Ramgarh, and Daltonganj. Major coal ﬁelds : West Bengal - Dalingkot (Darjeeling) Birbhum, Chinakuri. Madhya Pradesh - Singrauli, Suhagpur. Odisha - Talcher. Other Minerals in India : Copper - Found in Jhunjhunu and Alwar in Rajasthan. Limestone - Commonly found in Coimbatore and Madurai in Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Which is the world’s largest PV Solar Park located in one of the Indian states ?
questions.explanation: Bhadla Solar P ark. It is located in Rajasthan's Jodhpur district, spans 14,000 acres. The Pavagada Solar Park, located in Karnataka's Tumkur district. It was developed by Karnataka Solar Power Development Corporation (KSPDCL). Dholera Solar Park - Gujarat. Harshad Solar Park - Gujarat.

questions.question: Tertiary coals occur in which of the following states in India ?
questions.explanation: Meghala y a. Tertiary coals, which include lignite and sub-bituminous coal, occur in Assam, Arunachal Pradesh, Meghalaya and Nagaland. It is extracted from Darangiri, Cherrapunji, Mewlong and Langrin (Meghalaya); Makum, Jaipur and Nazira (Assam); Namchik - Namphuk (Arunachal Pradesh) and Kalakot (Jammu and Kashmir). The brown coal or lignite occurs in the coastal areas of Tamil Nadu, Pondicherry, Gujarat and Jammu and Kashmir.

questions.question: Koderma Gaya Hazaribagh belt is known for the production of which of the following minerals?
questions.explanation: Mica deposits are found on the northern edge of the Chota Nagpur Plateau, with the Koderma - Gaya - Hazaribagh belt in Jharkhand leading production. Major mica-producing regions include Gaya, Hazaribagh, Ajmer, Beawar, Bhilwara, Udaipur, Dungarpur, Banswara, and Nellore. The main mica-producing states are Jharkhand, Rajasthan, and Andhra Pradesh.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT among the commercial sources of energy?
questions.explanation: F uel wood. It is a non -commercial or traditional source of energy, primarily used for domestic purposes such as cooking and heating. Commercial sources of energy are typically: Fossil fuels (petroleum, coal, natural gas), Electricity (produced from a variety of energy sources), Hydropower (electricity generated from water resources).

questions.question: The Mumbai High region in the Arabian Sea is known for mining _______ .
questions.explanation: Miner al Oil. Other oil cities/states in India : Digboi is known as the Oil City of Assam where the ﬁrst oil well in Asia was drilled. Surma Valley (Assam), Rajasthan (Largest producer of Petroleum in India), Gujarat.

questions.question: The Gua and Noamundi mines are located in with state of India?
questions.explanation: Jharkhand. Noamundi and Gua are Iron ore Mines. Iron ore mines in Jharkhand: Kiriburu, Meghahatuburu, Chiria. Major reserves of haematite iron in India: Odisha, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Karnataka and Goa. Iron ore mines in India: Bailadila (Chattisgarh), Balda Block, Joda (Odisha).

questions.question: According to the Indian Minerals Yearbook 2020, which state has the highest production of manganese in India ?
questions.explanation: Madhy a Pr adesh (33%), followed by Maharashtra (24%) and Odisha (18%). Other Mineral producing states: Iron Ore - Odisha, Chhattisgarh and Karnataka. Chromite - Odisha, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. Nickel - Odisha, Jharkhand. Cobalt - Jharkhand, Odisha, Nagaland. Coal - Jharkhand, Orissa, Chattisgarh. Petroleum - Maharashtra, Gujarat.

questions.question: Which district of Madhya Pradesh is a leading producer of copper?
questions.explanation: Balaghat (Largest producer district of copper in India). Other Copper producing States (India) - Rajasthan(Khetri), Jharkhand (Singhbhum). Largest Copper producer (World) - Chile. Top Minerals Producers (India) - Bauxite (Odisha), Gold (Karnataka), Silver (Rajasthan), Coal (Jharkhand), Uranium (Andhra Pradesh).

questions.question: Which of the following is an open pit copper mine ?
questions.explanation: Malanjkhand (Madhya Pradesh) . Open-pit mining (opencast mining) - A surface mining technique that extracts minerals from an open pit in the ground. Copper Mines in India : Khetri (Rajasthan), Singhbhum (Jharkhand), Kolihan (Rajasthan), Surda (Jharkhand) etc.

questions.question: Which of the following regions in India is nicknamed as the storehouse of minerals?
questions.explanation: Chota Nagpur Plateau is a rich source of minerals, including mica, bauxite, copper, limestone, iron ore, coal, manganese ore, and chromite.

questions.question: What are the main energy sources for earth's internal heat engine?

options.a: Radiogenic heat and oceanic tide heat
options.b: Heat from volcanoes and solar heat
options.c: Solar heat and oceanic tide heat

questions.explanation: The Earth's heat is the internal heat that arises from two sources : The decay of radioactive isotopes in crustal rocks and the mantle, and primordial heat left over from the planet's ﬁer y formation. Geothermal energy is the heat produced deep in the Earth's core.

questions.question: The Bailadila range of Chhattisgarh is famous for which of the following minerals ?
questions.explanation: Ir on or e. Types of Iron Ore – Haematite, Magnetite, Limonite and Siderite. Mines and Iron deposit in India: Chhattisgarh - Dalli-Rajhara; Jharkhand - Noamundi mines; Karnataka - Kemmangundi (Baba Budan hills), Sandur (Bellary); Rajasthan - Jaipur, Udaipur, Jhunjhunu, Sikar, Bhilwara, Alwar, Bharatpur, Dausa and Banswara; Andhra Pradesh - Kurnool, Guntur, Cuddapah, Anantapur, Nellore; Kerala - Naduvallur, Eleyettimala, Nanminda, Alampara; Tamil Nadu - Kanjamalai, Mudumalai Hills (Salem district).

questions.question: The approximate amount of silica present in cement is:
questions.explanation: Between 17% and 25%. Cement - It was ﬁrst introduced in England in 1824 by Joseph Aspdin. Composition of Cement: Lime (60-65%), Silica (17-25%), Alumina (3-8%), Magnesia (1-3%), Iron oxide (0.5-6%), Calcium Sulfate (0.1-0.5%), Sulfur Trioxide (1-3%), Alkaline (0-1%).

questions.question: The Gulf of Khambhat, the Gulf of Kutch and Sundarbans region provide ideal conditions for utilizing ___________ energy in India.
questions.explanation: Tidal energy is a renewable energy source that harnesses the power of the ocean's tides to generate electricity. As of September 2024, Gujarat has the largest installed wind power generation capacity in India. Rajasthan ranks 1st among Indian states in terms of installed capacity of solar energy.

questions.question: Which stone could convert all baser metals like iron into gold?
questions.explanation: Philosopher ’ s st one. It is a legendary substance that was believed to have the power to transform base metals like iron into gold and also to grant immortality. Emer ald is a gemstone and a variety of the mineral beryl colored green by trace amounts of chromium or sometimes vanadium. Jade is a green coloured precious stone or a mineral used in jewelry and as an ornament.

questions.question: Which is the oldest oil producing state of India?
questions.explanation: Assam. India's ﬁrst oil reserve is located in Digboi city of Assamstate. Naharkatiya and Moran-Hugrijan are important oil ﬁelds of the state. The largest producer of petroleum in India is Rajasthan, followed by Gujarat and Assam. Oil ﬁelds of Rajasthan: Mangla, Bhagyam, Kameshwari. Gujarat oil ﬁelds: Ankleshwar , Kalol.

questions.question: Kawas Thermal Power Station is located in which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Gujar at. Thermal power station in India: Gujarat - Kutch, Sikka, Dhuvaran. Maharashtra - Bhusawal, Trombay, Khaparkheda. Rajasthan - Chhabra, Barsingsar, Suratgarh, Kota. West Bengal - Farakka Super, Kolaghat, Bakreshwar.

questions.question: The main mineral constituents of the continental mass are ____ and _____ .
questions.explanation: Silica, alumina. It is often termed Sial (Si-silica and Al - aluminum). Ear th (three layers): Crust, Mantle, and Core. Crust (outermost) - It is about 5 km thick under the oceans and about 30 km thick under the continents. Mantle - The major constituent elements are silicon and Magnesium. Cor e (mostly Iron and nickel) - This is the innermost layer of the earth.

questions.question: Which state among the following has the largest reserves of gold ore in India as of 2021?
questions.explanation: Bihar . Karnataka (Land of Gold) produces 80% of the gold in India. Thr ee gold ﬁ elds in India - Kolar Gold Field (Karnataka), Kolar Hutti Gold ﬁ eld (Karnataka) and Ramgiri Gold Fields (Andhra Pradesh). Largest producer of Gold in the world - China. The largest producers of gold ore - Bihar (44%), Rajasthan (25%), Karnataka (21%), West Bengal (3%) and Jharkhand (2%).

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding coal is NOT correct?

options.a: Anthracite is the highest quality hard coal.
options.b: Coal that has been buried deep and subjected to increased temperatures isbituminous coal.
options.c: Lignite is a low-grade brown coal, which is soft with high moisture content.
options.d: Metallurgical coal is high grade lignite coal which has a special value for smelting iron in blast furnaces.

questions.explanation: Coal is the most important and abundant fossil fuel in India. It is variously referred to as the 'black gold' or 'black diamond'. It contains carbon, volatile matter, moisture, and ash.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a major iron ore belt in India?
questions.explanation: Har y ana-Rajasthan belt. The major iron ore belts in India are Odisha- Jharkhand belt : High grade haematite ore is found in Badampahar mines in the Mayurbhanj and Kendujhar districts.

questions.question: The largest wind farm cluster of India is located in ______.
questions.explanation: T amil Nadu. The name of this wind farm is Muppandal Wind Farm, located in Muppandal, Kanyakumari district, Tamil Nadu. It is an onshore wind farm with a capacity of 1,500 MW. The largest wind farm in the world is the Gansu Wind Farm in China.

questions.question: The major resources of Gondwana coal, which are metallurgical coal is located in______.
questions.explanation: Damodar v alle y (West Bengal -Jharkhand). Jharia, Raniganj, Bokaro are important coal ﬁ elds. The Godavari, Mahanadi, Son and Wardha valleys also contain coal deposits. Q.292 . Peat coal has ____ carbon and ____ moisture content? SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (1st Shift) (a) High, Low (b) Low, high (c) High, High (d) Low, Low Sol.292.(b) Low , high. Peat is a soft, dark brown coal that is formed from dead and decaying organic matter. It has an energy density of 15 MJ/kg. It has a low heating capacity. India has the ﬁfth-lar gest coal reserves in the world. Coal India Limited (CIL) (Public Sector Undertaking) was established on 1 November 1975 under the ownership of the Ministry of Coal. Headquarters: Kolkata.

questions.question: In which of the following states of India, the reserves of silver are NOT found?
questions.explanation: Gujar at. Silv er mines in India: Zawar mines and Sindesar Khurd Mine (Rajasthan), Tundoo Lead Smelter and Moubandar smelter (Jharkhand), Kolar ﬁelds and Hutti Mine (Karnataka), Vizag Zinc smelter (Andhra Pradesh).

questions.question: Which of the following is a large group of rock-forming silicate minerals that constitutes more than 50% of the Earth's crust and is widely used in the glass and ceramic industries?
questions.explanation: F eldspars are a group of rock-forming aluminum tectosilicate minerals, containing sodium, calcium, potassium, or barium. They are used as ﬂuxing agents in ceramics and glass applications, and also are used as functional ﬁllers in the paint, plastic, rubber and adhesive industries.

questions.question: Which of the following minerals is NOT found in rivers (alluvial placers) and on the coast, especially beaches (beach placers)?
questions.explanation: Bauxite deposits are formed by the decomposition of a wide variety of rocks rich in aluminium silicates.

questions.question: Which of the following is an Export Processing Zone (EPZ) set up in West Bengal?
questions.explanation: F alta. An Export Processing Zone (EPZ) is a Customs area where one is allowed to import plant, machinery, equipment and material for the manufacture of export goods under security, without payment of duty.

questions.question: In which of the following states are the Sundargarh deposits of Manganese located?
questions.explanation: Odisha . Manganese deposits are available in Sundargarh, Keonjhar, Rayagada, and Balangir districts in Odisha. Dolomite is available in plenty only in the district of Sundergarh.

questions.question: Which of the following states has one of the richest monazite deposits in India?
questions.explanation: K er ala. The world's richest monazite deposits occur in the Palakkad and Kollam districts of Kerala. Nuclear minerals in India primarily comprises Thorium and very few reserves of Uranium.

questions.question: In which of the following states is shifting agriculture locally called Penda ?
questions.explanation: A ndhr a Pr adesh. In India, shifting agriculture is called ‘Bewar’ or ‘Dahiya’ in Madhya Pradesh, ‘Podu’ or ‘Penda’ in Andhra Pradesh, ‘Pama Dabi’ or ‘Koman’ or ‘Bringa’ in Odisha, ‘Kumari’ in Western Ghats, ‘Valre’ or ‘Waltre’ in South-eastern Rajasthan, ‘Khil’ in the Himalayan belt, ‘Kuruwa’ in Jharkhand, and‘Jhumming’ in the North-eastern region.

questions.question: The term 'Aus', 'Aman' and 'Boro' are associated with which crop in India?
questions.explanation: P addy is basically a tropical crop. 'Aus', 'Aman' and 'Boro' are grown in states like Assam, West Bengal, and Odisha throughout the year. Aus: Sown in the summer, along with pre-monsoonal rains, and harvested in the autumn. Aman: Sown in the monsoon and harvested in the winter. Boro: Sown in the winter and harvested in the summer.

questions.question: Which type of tea in large amount is exported from India to importing countries?
questions.explanation: Black tea. India is the world's second largest tea producer after China. The types of tea exported through Indiaare: Black tea, Regular tea, Green tea, Herbal tea, Masala tea, and Lemon tea. The majority of the tea exported out of India is black tea which makes up about 96% of the total exports.

questions.question: The people of Himachal Pradesh make channels to bring water from a glacier or rainwater to villages for the function of mainly irrigation. These channels are locally known as:
questions.explanation: Guls or K uls. In hill and mountainous regions, people built diversion channels like the ‘guls’ or ‘kuls’ of the Western Himalayas for agriculture. Water harvesting system: ‘Rooftop rain water harvesting’ was commonly practised to store drinking water, particularly in Rajasthan. In arid and semi-arid regions, agricultural ﬁelds were converted into rain fed storage structures that allowed the water to stand and moisten the soil like the ‘khadins’ in Jaisalmer and ‘Johads’ in other parts of Rajasthan. Roof top rain water harvesting is the most common practice in Shillong, Meghalaya.

questions.question: Which of the following states is the biggest producer of Pulses?
questions.explanation: Madhy a Pr adesh. Based on the production estimates for the year 2022-23, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra and Rajasthan are the top three pulses producing states in the country. India is the largest producer of pulses in the world.

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly de ﬁ nes the green revolution?

options.a: It is a new strategy in agriculture to produce food grains, especially wheat and rice.
options.b: It is a new strategy to increase the share of the forest.
options.c: It is a new strategy to use green colour for all purposes.
options.d: It is a new strategy to use only herbal products.

questions.explanation: The Green Revolution, starting in the 1960s, aimed to achieve food security and reduce food imports, particularly in India. It involved the introduction of high-yielding variety seeds, mechanized farming, improved irrigation, and the use of pesticides and fertilizers.

questions.question: According to the Agricultural and Processed food products Export Development Authority (APEDA) 2020-2021, which state of India has the ﬁrst rank in grapes production?
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a. APEDA was established in 1986, operates under the Ministry of Commerce and Trade to promote the export of agricultural and processed food products.

questions.question: The green revolution technology resulted in an increase in production of cereal production from 72.4 million tons in 1965-66 to ________ million tons in 1978-79.
questions.explanation: 131.9. The cereal production was increased due to three factors: (i) Increase in net area under cultivation; (ii) Growing two or more crops in a year on the same piece of land; and (iii) Use of HYV seeds.

questions.question: The headquarters of the second Green Revolution cell was in ________.
questions.explanation: P atna. The headquarters of the Second Green Revolution (SGR) Cell is located at ICAR-Research Complex for Eastern Region (RCER), Patna. The SGR Cell was created by the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers' Welfare, Government of India to improve agricultural productivity and livelihood in the Eastern region of India because the bene ﬁ ts of ﬁrst Green Revolution were mainly con ﬁ ned to north-western states of Haryana, Punjab and western Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the aims of National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture (NMSA) of India is/are correct? 1.To make agriculture more productive. 2.To make agriculture more sustainable. 3.To promote organic farming.
questions.explanation: 1, 2 and 3 ar e corr ect.National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture (NMSA) has been made operational from the year 2014-15 which aims at making agriculture more productive, sustainable, remunerative and climate resilient by promoting location speci ﬁ c integrated /composite farming systems; soil and moisture conservation measures; comprehensive soil health management; eﬃcient water management practices and mainstreaming rainfed technologies.

questions.question: What was a signi ﬁ cant negative environmental impact of the Green Revolution?
questions.explanation: Soil degr adation. The Green Revolution caused soil fertility loss through the use of chemical fertilizers. Chemical fertilizers also kill bacteria and other microorganisms in the soil. Green Revolution also led to groundwater depletion due to extensive tubewell irrigation, impacting long-term environmental resources.

questions.question: How was the growth in all food grains after the Green Revolution?
questions.explanation: Dispr opor tionate. Larger farmers with more resources were able to afford the necessary inputs, like high-yield variety (HYV) seeds, fertilizers, and irrigation, and thus reaped greater bene ﬁ ts. Smaller farmers often lacked access to these resources and faced higher risks, as the HYV crops were more vulnerable to pests, potentially causing severe losses. About 65 percent of the country’s population continued to be employed in agriculture even as late as 1990. Q.311 . What was the main objective of the Second Green Revolution in India? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Ensuring food security in the western states (b) Promoting conventional agricultural practices (c) Focusing on holistic development in agriculture (d) Increasing the use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides Sol.311.(c) In the second phase of the green revolution (mid-1970s tomid-1980s), the HYV technology spread to a larger number of states and bene ﬁ ted more variety of crops. The spread of green revolution technology enabled India to achieve self-su ﬃ ciency in food grains.

questions.question: Which of the following movements created regional disparities between large and small farmers in India?
questions.explanation: Gr een r e v olution in India started with the aim of increasing India's agricultural production to make India self-su ﬃ cient in food grains.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are correct? i. The ﬁrst green revolution led to over-exploitation of natural resources. ii. The second Green Revolution was more focused on Southern India. iii. The second green revolution ensured in achieving sustainable livelihood security.
questions.explanation: i and iii. The Second Green Revolution focuses on sustainable agriculture in eastern India, rainfed areas, and small farmers, promoting climate-resilient practices and livelihood security.

questions.question: What action was taken by the government to celebrate the achievement of the Green Revolution in agriculture?

options.a: Released a regular salary for the farmers
options.b: Distributed free food to all the people
options.d: Distributed green vegetables to the people

questions.explanation: Green Revolution : The term was ﬁrst used by William Gaud, with Norman Borlaug recognized as its global father and M.S. Swaminathan was the father of the Green Revolution in India. India adopted a new agricultural strategy, boosting wheat and rice production. In July 1968, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi commemorated its success by releasing a special stamp titled "Wheat Revolution."

questions.question: What is the economic justi ﬁ cation for subsidies in the agriculture sector?

options.a: It is mostly used to provide bene ﬁ ts for rich farmers.
options.b: It is a part of government expenditure in the service sector.
options.c: It is an incentive to provide the bene ﬁ ts of advanced technology and decrease the cost of production.
options.d: It is used to provide bene ﬁ ts for capital goods producers in agriculture.

questions.explanation: Agricultural subsidies support food security and development by helping farmers boost production, improve food availability, and reduce poverty. Input subsidies lower costs, incentivize adoption, increase productivity, and stimulate economic growth.

questions.question: In West Bengal, how many rice crops are grown in a year?
questions.explanation: Thr ee. In states like Assam, West Bengal, and Odisha, three paddy crops are grown annually: Aus, Aman, and Boro.

questions.question: Which state in India was the most transformed by the Green Revolution?
questions.explanation: Punjab. The Green Revolution primarily bene ﬁ ted Punjab, Haryana, and western Uttar Pradesh in the north, and Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu in the south. It had minimal impact on the eastern region, including Assam, Bihar, West Bengal, Orissa, and the arid regions of western and southern India.

questions.question: In the given main characteristics of farming which is NOT a characteristic of the Indian commercial farming?
questions.explanation: Slash and burn farming is a form of shifting agriculture where natural vegetation is cut down and burned to clear the land for cultivation. In commercial farming, higher doses of modern inputs are used to obtain higher productivity. The degree of commercialization in agriculture varies from one region to another. For example, rice is a commercial crop in Haryana and Punjab, but in Odisha, it is a subsistencecrop.

questions.question: Which of the following types of crops are sown after the end of the monsoon season?
questions.explanation: Rabi cr ops. It is an agricultural crop that is sown in the winter and harvested in the spring.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the consequences of the Green Revolution?

options.b: Rising prices and a shift in the mode of payment of agricultural workers from payment in cash to payment in kind (grain)
options.d: The rich grew richer and many of the poor stagnated or grew poorer

questions.explanation: Impact of Green Revolution : Positive - Increase in production and productivity of food grains, reduction in hunger, and technological advancements in agriculture. Negative - Decline in Soil fertility, High production costs, Regional disparities ।

questions.question: Match the following names of primitive forms of cultivation in different states correctly.StatesName of Primitiv e form of cultiv ation 1. Madhya Pradesh a. Penda 2. Andhra Pradesh b. Bewar 3. Odisha c. Kuruwa 4. Jharkhand d. Bringa

Match the items in List I with those in List II.List I List II i. Blue revolution a. Oilseeds ii. Yellow revolution b. Overall horticulture iii. Round revolution c. Fish iv. Golden revolution d. Potato
questions.explanation: i-c, ii-a, iii -d, iv-b. Agricultural Revolutions in India: GreenRevolution - To increase agricultural productivity, White Revolution - Milk production, Black Revolution - Petroleum products, Brown Revolution - Leather / Cocoa / Non-Conventional Products, Golden Fiber Revolution - Jute Production, Silver Revolution - Egg Production / Poultry Production, Red Revolution - Meat Production / Tomato Production.

questions.question: Which of the following types of crops are sown at the beginning of the monsoon season?
questions.explanation: Kharif cr ops. These crops are typically planted during June to September and harvested in the post-monsoon season (October to November). Examples of Kharif crops include rice, maize, cotton, and sorghum. Rabi crops are sown after the monsoon season, usually in the winter months (October to December), and harvested in the spring (March to May). Zaid crops are grown in the intervening period between Kharif and Rabi seasons, typically in the summer months (March to June).

questions.question: Which of the following statement/s about the Green Revolution is/are CORRECT? i. India became self-su ﬃ cient with the introduction of the Green Revolution. ii. The Green Revolution led to loss of nutrients in the soil from farming the same crop over and over again. iii. The Green Revolution led to depletion of fresh ground water.
questions.explanation: i, ii and iii. The Green Revolution resulted in a great increase in production of food grains (especially wheat and rice) due to the introduction into developing countries of new, high-yielding variety (HYV) seeds. The green revolution enabled the government to procure su ﬃ cient amounts of food grains to build a stock which could be used in times of food shortage.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true about the positive impact of the Green Revolution (GR) on yield levels in India? i. During the post GR period, the yield of rice grew at a much faster rate than that of wheat. ii. GR technology had penetrated more in wheat crop than in the rice crop. iii. During post GR period, the area under rice achieved a relatively slow growth when compared to the area under wheat.
questions.explanation: Only ii and iii. The Green Revolution technology had a greater impact on wheat crops than on rice crops. Important Crops in the Revolution: Main crops were - Wheat, Rice, Jowar, Bajra and Maize. Non-food grains were excluded from the ambit of the new strategy. Wheat remained the mainstay of the Green Revolution for years. Mankombu Sambasivan Swaminathan is known as the "Father of India's Green Revolution" for his work to increase food production and alleviate world hunger.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT true of the second phase of the green revolution?

options.a: It was adopted by farmers living in dry and semi-arid regions of India.
options.b: It was launched in areas with a signi ﬁ cant shift from dry to wet (irrigated) cultivation.
options.c: It covered the period of the 1960s and 1970s.
options.d: It covered the period of the 1980s.

questions.explanation: The use of HYV seeds was restricted to the more a ﬄ uent states such as Punjab, Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu in the 1st Phase(Mid 1960s to mid-1970s). In the second phase of the green revolution (mid-1970s to mid-1980s), the HYV technology spread to a larger number of states and bene ﬁ ted more variety of crops.

questions.question: Who among the following is NOT associated with the Green Revolution?
questions.explanation: P Chidambar am. Green Revolution: Initiated by - Norman Borlaug (1960s). He is known as the ‘Father of Green Revolution’ in world. He received the Nobel prize (1970) for developing High yielding varieties (HYVs) of wheat. M.S. Swaminathan (Father of Green Revolution in India). The Green revolution came under the third ﬁv e year plan (1961-66). Chidambaram Subramaniam was an Indian politician and agricultural scientist who played a crucial role in India's Green Revolution. Award - BharatRatna (1998).

questions.question: Identify the crop which is grown in Kharif cropping season in Northern States of India.
questions.explanation: Rice. Kharif is sown during the rainy season, typically from June to September in India. Examples include paddy, maize, soybean, groundnut, and cotton. Rabi grows in the winter season, from October to March. Examples include wheat, gram, peas, mustard, and linseed. In between the rabi and the kharif seasons, there is a short season during the summer months known as the Zaid season. Examples are watermelon, muskmelon, cucumber.

questions.question: In which of the following ways were farmers encouraged to begin to use high yielding variety seeds ?

options.a: Farmers’ children were given free education in government colleges and universities.
options.b: Agricultural labourers were paid wages directly by the government.
options.c: Farmers were given monetary support in cash to cultivate food grains.
options.d: The government provided seeds and other inputs at prices lower than those prevailing in the market.

questions.explanation: Farmers were encouraged to use high-yielding variety (HYV) seeds during the Green Revolution through various forms of support from the government. The government made HYV seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, and irrigation systems available at subsidized prices, meaning they were cheaper than market rates. This helped reduce the ﬁnancial burden on farmers and incentivized them to adopt new agricultural technologies. HYV seeds are resistant to insects and diseases and are known for their high yields.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an agro-based industry?
questions.explanation: F er tiliser . Agro-based industries depend on agricultural raw materials, producing mainly consumer goods. Major industries include cotton, jute, textiles, and edible oil. India's ﬁrst sugar mill was established in Pratappur, Uttar Pradesh, in 1903. The Sugar Cane Act of 1934 allowed state governments to set the minimum price for sugarcane.Q.331. Which of the following is NOT true with regard to the Green Revolution? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Cultivation became more intensive in nature. (b) In its second phase, there was a shift to from dry to wet (irrigated) cultivation in dry and semi-arid regions of India. (c) Cultivation became more extensive in nature. (d) There was change in the cropping pattern and types of crops grown in its second phase. Sol.331.(c) The Green Revolution did not focus on expanding the area under cultivation but rather on making the existing land more productive (intensive cultivation), using modern inputs and technology.

questions.question: Which crops are bene ﬁ tted from the temperate cyclones arising from the Mediterranean Sea that cause rainfall in Punjab?
questions.explanation: Rabi cr ops. Temperate cyclones cause rainfall in Punjab, Haryana, Delhi and western Uttar Pradesh. The precipitation is in the form of snowfall in the lower Himalayas. It is this snow that sustains the ﬂow of water in the Himalayan rivers during the summer months. The precipitation goes on decreasing from west to east in the plains and from north to south in the mountains.

questions.question: In July 1968, Indira Gandhi, the then Prime Minister of India, o ﬃ cially recorded impressive strides of the Green Revolution in agriculture by releasing a special stamp entitled _________ .
questions.explanation: Wheat Re v olution (Part of Green Revolution) was initiated under the Third Five Year Plan (1961-66) by introducing high-yielding varieties of seeds of rice and wheat.

questions.question: Which of the following reasons can be attributed to the excessive pressure on agricultural land in India? a) Right of inheritance b) Size of unpro ﬁ table land holding c) Division of land d) Multiple cropping
questions.explanation: a, b and c. Reasons that cause pressure on Agriculture: The right of inheritance, Division of land, Rising population, Use of Excessive Chemical Fertilizer, Salinization of soil, Deserti ﬁ cation, Urbanisation, Waterlogging, Climate Change, Droughts, Pollution etc.

questions.question: Which of the following countries is related with high yielding variety seeds that are used as part of Green Revolution policies in India?
questions.explanation: Mexico. Gr een Re v olution - A period that began in the 1960s during which agriculture in India was converted into a modern industrial system by the adoption of technology (The use of high yielding variety (HYV) seeds, mechanised farm tools, irrigation facilities, pesticides, and fertilizers).

questions.question: Which of the following varieties of rice is known as the miracle rice for India and was ﬁrst harvested in 1967 with exceptional yield?
questions.explanation: IR8. It is a high-yielding semi-dwarf rice variety developed by the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI). IR8 is also called miracle rice, which helped save India from a massive famine. Golden rice: A transgenic rice having a gene for carotene. It was ﬁrst intr oduced in 1999 by Ingo Potrykus and Peter Beyer. It contains pro-vitamin A which upon ingestion is converted to vitamin A in the human body.

questions.question: For Kharif crops, the temperature required for farming is above 25 degrees Celsius with high humidity and annual rainfall above ________ cm.
questions.explanation: 100. Kharif cr ops are sown during the monsoon season, which lasts from June to September in India.

questions.question: The agricultural land below the main canal water level forms the ________.
questions.explanation: command ar ea. Lift system - Water is lifted from lower level to higherlevel with the help of pumps and other equipment. Flow system - The type of irrigation in which water is available at a higher level to enable supply to the land by gravity ﬂow . Warabandi - It is a system of rotation of supply of water according to a predetermined schedule as per area and crop needs specifying the day, time and duration of supply to each holding to ensure equitable water distribution among farmers of an outlet command.

questions.question: _______ land is suitable for regular cropping.
questions.explanation: Ar able land is the land under temporary crops, temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and temporary fallow. It is capable of being ploughed and used to grow crops. Barren land - Land that normally cannot be brought under cultivation with the available technology. Marginal land - Land that has little or no agricultural Value.

questions.question: Which group of crops belong to ﬁbr e crops and are produced on a large scale in India ?
questions.explanation: Jute and Hemp. Jute is known as Golden Fibre. It grows well on well-drained fertile soils in the ﬂoodplains. MajorJute producing states (West Bengal, Bihar, Assam, Odisha and Meghalaya).

questions.question: Which of the following crops is the only genetically modi ﬁ ed (GM) crop approved for commercial cultivation in India?
questions.explanation: Bt Cott on. GM cr ops : These are derived from plants whose genes are artiﬁ cially modiﬁ ed, usually by inserting genetic material from another organism. India approved the release of Bt cotton (Cry 1 AC) for commercial cultivation in 2002 - Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Karnataka, and Tamil Nadu. The best known variety of GM rice is golden rice.

questions.question: Cultivating large farms with moderately low inputs of labour and capital is referred to as ________.
questions.explanation: Extensiv e cultiv ation - The crop yield depends on the natural fertility of the soil, terrain, climate, availability of water. Example - Grain Farming, shifting cultivation. Hybrid cultiv ation - It involves the use of hybrid seed varieties (created by crossbreeding two or more genetically distinct plants). Example - Wheat - Sonalika and Kalyan Sona, Rice - Jaya and Ratna.

questions.question: Which of the following crops is classi ﬁ ed as ﬁne grain?
questions.explanation: Wheat. India produces a variety of cereals, which are classi ﬁ ed into ﬁne grains (rice, wheat) and coarse grains (jowar, bajra, maize, ragi, etc.).

questions.question: Which of the following is the most suitable application of rainwater harvesting?
questions.explanation: Irrigation. Rainwater harvesting is the process of collecting, storing, and purifying rainwater from rooftops, parks, roads, and open grounds. It is used for drinking, domestic needs, livestock, small irrigation, and replenishing groundwater levels.

questions.question: What is meant by subsistence agriculture ?

options.a: Agricultural output is su ﬃ cient for the country.
options.c: Agriculture generates su ﬃ cient income.
options.d: Agriculturists produce primarily for the market.

questions.explanation: T ypes of Subsistence F arming : Primitiv e subsistence farming or shifting cultiv ation (oldest form of agriculture) - It happens on a self-su ﬃ cient basis, and farmers raise food according to their family’s needs. The trees are cut down and burnt and the cleared land is cultivated. Other names: Shifting cultivation or slash and burn cultivation. Intensiv e subsistence farming - The farmer cultivates a small plot of land using simple tools and more. More than one crop is cultivated during a year.

questions.question: Which of the following states of India still uses the ancient bamboo drip irrigation method?
questions.explanation: Meghala y a. Bamboo drip irrigation system is tapping stream and spring water by using bamboo pipes. T ypes of Irrigation systems: Well and Tube well, Canal, Tank, Drip, Sprinkler, Furrow, Surge, Ditch. The word Meghalaya means “abode of clouds”. ‘Krem Liat Prah’ Longest cave of India is in Meghalaya. Hills: Garo, Khasi, Jaintia.

questions.question: Which of the following classi ﬁ cation bases of industry applies to the products - cotton, jute, wool, silk textile, rubber, tea, sugar, coffee, edible oil ?
questions.explanation: Agr o-based industries use plant and animal products as raw materials. Mineral-based industries, like iron and steel, copper smelting, and cement, use mineral ores. Consumer industries produce goods for direct consumer use, such as sugar, toothpaste, paper, sewing machines, and fans.

questions.question: 54.6% of the total workforce is engaged in _________ and allied sector activities (Census of India 2011).
questions.explanation: Agricultur e. Census 2011 was conducted by the Registrar General of India. The total number of agricultural workers in the country : 263.1 million (118.8 million cultivators and 144.3 million agricultural labourers) in 2011. The workforce participation rate for females was 25.51% against 53.26% for males.

questions.question: Cultivation of rice needs high rainfall ________.
questions.explanation: High temper atur e and high humidity . Fertile riverine alluvial soil is best for rice cultivation. It is a type of Kharif crop. West Bengal is the largest rice-producing state in India. China is the world's largest producer of rice followed by India. Methane is the gas produced by the rice ﬁeld.

questions.question: The cultivation of ________ was introduced on the Baba Budan Hills in India.
questions.explanation: Coff ee . Baba Budan introduced the coffee plant to Chikkamanglur, Karnataka in 1670. Growth of coffee was encouraged during the time of General Sir Mark Cubbon in 1834. Types of coffee bean : Arabica, Robusta, Excelsa and Liberica. Coffee producer country: 1st- Brazil. 2nd- Vietnam. Q.351 . Dr D.S. Athwal was known as the 'Father of___________Revolution in India'. SSC CGL 21/07/2023 (1st shift) (a) Oilseed (b) Rice (c) Millet (d) Wheat Sol.351.(d) Wheat. F ather of Agricultur al r e v olutions in India : Gr een Revolution (Agriculture) - M.S. Swaminathan, White Revolution or Operation ﬂood (Milk/ Dairy products) - Dr. Varghese Kurien, Blue Revolution (Fish and Aqua) - Dr. Arun Krishnan and Dr. Harilal Chaudhari, Golden Revolution (Fruits, Honey, Horticulture) - Nirpakh Tutaj, Silv er Revolution (Eggs) - Indira Gandhi, Y ellow Revolution (Oil Seeds) - Sam Pitroda, Pink Revolution (Pharmaceuticals, Prawns, Onion) - Durgesh Patel, Br own Revolution (Leather, Coco) - Hiralal Chaudri, Red Revolution (Meat, Tomato) - Vishal Tewari.

questions.question: "Agricultural Census" is conducted in India at an interval of _____.
questions.explanation: Fiv e y ears. The Agriculture Census in India is conducted following the broad guidelines of the decennial World Census of Agriculture (WCA) developed by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations. The Agriculture Census has been conducted by the Ministry of Agriculture since 1970-71. “The Ele v enthAgricultur al Census” (2021-22) Launched by The Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare.

questions.question: Which of the following is termed as "sericulture" ?
questions.explanation: Commer cial r earing of silkworms. ‘Bombyx mori', ‘Eri’, ‘Muga’ and ‘Tasar’ are silkworm species used in sericulture. These are used to produce silkﬁber (protein) from their silk glands . Moriculture refers to the cultivation of mulberry plants. Other types of farming : Aviculture (birds), Apiculture (bees), Pisciculture ( ﬁ sh), Viticulture (grapes), Fungiculture (mushroom), Arboriculture (tree), Silviculture (fodder crops), Olericulture (vegetables).

questions.question: There are regions where farmers specialize in vegetables only. This type of farming is known as ______.
questions.explanation: T ruck farming. Mixed farming includes crop cultivation and raising animals. Pastoral farming involves livestock, such as cattle, sheep, and goats, while dairy farming focuses on milk production from cows.

questions.question: Which among the following terms means growing of fruits?
questions.explanation: P omicultur e. A picultur e - The maintenance of honeybees and hives. Arboricultur e - Cultivation of trees, shrubs, and woody plants for shading and decorating.

questions.question: It is a tropical as well as a subtropical crop. It grows well in hot and humid climates with a temperature of 21°C to 27°C and an annual rainfall between 75cm and 100cm. Which of the crops is being talked about in the information given above?
questions.explanation: Sugar cane. India is the second-largest producer of sugarcane after Brazil. Maiz e - Grown in tropics, sub-tropics and temperate regions. Rubber - Equatorial crop produced primarily for the manufacture of latex for industrial use.

questions.question: Cotton requires ____ temperature, light rainfall or irrigation,_____ frost - free days and bright sun-shine for its growth.
questions.explanation: High, 210. Cotton crop requires light rainfall or irrigation and bright sunshine for its growth. It comes under the Kharif Crop.

questions.question: In India initially HYVP was implemented in about how much area?
questions.explanation: 2 million hectar es. HYVP (High Yielding Variety Programme) was restricted to only ﬁv e crops – Wheat, rice, jowar, bajra and maize. The high yielding variety of seeds (resistant to insects and diseases) played an important role in the Green Revolution of India.

questions.question: In rainforests which kind of cultivation is practiced?
questions.explanation: Slash and burn cultivation or swidden cultivation, is commonly practiced in rainforest areas.

questions.question: The Purple revolution was launched by the Union Ministry of Science & Technology in Jammu and Kashmir. This revolution is related to cultivation of which crop?
questions.explanation: La v ender . The Purple Re v olution was initiated in 2016 through the Ar oma Mission of the Council of Scienti ﬁ c and Industrial Research (CSIR). In India, the lavender crop is cultivated in low rainfall regions and on the slopes of hills of Himachal Pradesh (HP) and Uttar Pradesh (UP).

questions.question: The Planning commission of India has divided India into how many Agro-climatic Zones?
questions.explanation: 15. Agr o-climatic z ones -Western Himalayan Region, Eastern Himalayan Region, Lower Gangetic Plains Region, Middle Gangetic Plains Region, Upper Gangetic Plains Region, Trans Gangetic Plains Region, Eastern plateau and Hills Region, Central Plateau and Hills, Western Plateau and Hills, Southern Plateau and Hills, East Coast Plains and Hills, West Coast Plains and Ghats Region, Gujarat Plains, Western Dry Region, Island region.

questions.question: Which crop does not require high rainfall and high temperature?
questions.explanation: Maiz e (Queen of cereals) is a kharif crop which requires a temperature between 21°C to 27°C and grows well in old alluvial soil. Rice is a kharif crop which requires high temperature (above 25°C) and high humidity with annual rainfall above 100 cm.

questions.question: Soilless agriculture is called ____.
questions.explanation: Hy dr oponics . In shifting agricultur e, a clearing is made in the forest, usually on the slopes of hills. Dr y farming is the cultivation of crops without irrigation in regions of limited moisture, typically less than 20 inches of precipitation annually.

questions.question: The word agriculture is derived from the Latin words ager and culture. What does ‘ager’ mean?
questions.explanation: Soil. The English word agriculture derives from the Latin ager (ﬁ eld) and colo (cultivate) signifying, when combined, the Latin agricultura: ﬁeld or land tillage. Agriculture is the art and science of cultivating the soil, growing crops and raising livestock. It is the backbone of the Indian economy.

questions.question: What is the percentage of land used for agriculture in India as per the 2009 data by National Institute of Hydrology?
