questions.explanation: 51.09%. In India, land is 21.81% under forest and 3.92% under pasture. National Institute of Hydrology has been in IIT- Roorkee, Uttarakhand since 1978. Its four Regional centers:Belagavi (Karnataka), Jammu, Kakinada (Andhra Pradesh), and Bhopal (Madhya Pradesh), and two Flood Management Studies Centre: Guwahati (Assam) and Patna (Bihar).

questions.question: DDT adversely affects our environment because:

options.a: it can kill bene ﬁ cial insects like honey bees
options.b: it can allow growth of harmful insects
options.c: it can promote growth of harmful insects

questions.explanation: DDT, Dichloro - diphenyl - trichloroethane (C14H9Cl5) is an insecticide used in agriculture. Its usage started in the 1940s to combat diseases like Malaria. High amounts of DDT exposure can lead to problems with the nervous system and liver. The US banned it in 1972 and it was banned worldwide. India produced it in the year 2009 to control visceral leishmaniasis and insect-born malaria disease.

questions.question: India lost a large proportion of ___ growing area to Pakistan during partition.
questions.explanation: Cott on is a key ﬁber and cash crop in India, with Gujarat and Maharashtra as leading producers. The ﬁrst cotton mill, Bombay Spinning and Weaving Company, was established in Bombay on 7 July 1854. Madhya Pradesh is the largest producer of soybeans, Karnataka of sunﬂ ower, and West Bengal of jute.

questions.question: Which of the following is the main food crop of the semi-arid areas of central and southern India?
questions.explanation: Jowar is mainly concentrated in the peninsular and central India. Karnataka is the highest maize producer. Rajasthan is the state with the highest yield of bajra in India. Karnataka is the leading producer of ragi in the country followed by Tamil Nadu, Uttarakhand, Maharashtra and Andhra Pradesh.

questions.question: Which of the following is a well - known variety of coffee initially brought to India from Yemen?
questions.explanation: Ar abica is grown in Karnataka (Kodagu, Chikkamagaluru, Hassan), Kerala (Malabar region), and Tamil Nadu (Nilgiris, Yercaud, Kodaikanal).

questions.question: Which of the following is a variety of oilseed?
questions.explanation: T ar amir a is an important oilseed cr op of drier regions of north-western India. The oil is not directly eaten, although it is mixed with mustard oil to increase the pungency of the latter. Ar abica, Robusta, and the less common Liberica and Ex celsa are the four main types of coffee beans.

questions.question: The _________ water utilization is very high in the states of Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan, and Tamil Nadu.
questions.explanation: Gr ound . The reason behind this is these states are advanced agricultural states and the share of the agriculture sector in water utilisation is much higher than any other sectors. Punjab in terms of land under irrigation leads in the country's States and UT's with 98.8 % of its cropland.

questions.question: A policy which involves ﬁxing the maximum size of land which could be owned by an individual is called _______.
questions.explanation: Land Ceiling. It minimizes inequality in land ownership and thus reduces inequality of income. The Urban Land Ceiling Act that was passed in 1976 proposed that there should be an equal distribution of land in urban agglomerations to subserve the common good.

questions.question: In a laterite soil pro ﬁ le, which of the following elements is present in an excessive amount?
questions.explanation: Ir on. Laterite soil contains excess iron due to intense leaching in high rainfall and temperature areas. The leaching process removes lime and silica, leaving iron oxide and aluminum compounds. These soils are poor innitrogen, phosphate, and calcium, making them less fertile naturally. However, after adding manures and fertilizers, they are suitable for tree crops like cashew nuts.

questions.question: Which of the following factors is primarily responsible for soil formation?
questions.explanation: W eathering : It involves the breakdown of rocks and minerals into smaller particles through exposure to environmental factors like wind, water, ice, temperature ﬂuctuations and others. Irrigation : It supports agriculture and affects soil moisture. Degradation : This refers to the deterioration of soil quality. Mining : It can disturb existing soils.

questions.question: Which plateaus are very fertile because they are rich in black soil that is very good for farming?
questions.explanation: Deccan la v a plateau is a volcanic plateau in west-central India that was formed by the solidi ﬁ cation of lava from deep within the Earth. It is a triangular landmass that lies to the south of the river Narmada. The African plateau is famous for gold and diamond mining. The Katanga Plateau in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is known for its rich deposits of copper and uranium.

questions.question: Which of the following is the main cause of land degradation in Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh?
questions.explanation: Defor estation due t o mining. Human activities like deforestation, over-grazing, mining, and quarrying signi ﬁ cantly contribute to land degradation. Deforestation due to mining has severely impacted states like Jharkhand and Odisha. Over-grazing affects Gujarat, Rajasthan, and Madhya Pradesh, while excessive irrigation causes waterlogging and soil degradation in Punjab, Haryana, and western Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: Which type of soil is found on about 40% of the total area of India?
questions.explanation: Alluvial soil is deposited by surface water, commonly found in river valleys and northern plains. It is highly fertile and rich in humus and lime. Crops cultivated on it include sugarcane, rice, maize, wheat, oilseeds, and pulses.

questions.question: Which is the largest part of the northern plains and is formed of older alluvium?
questions.explanation: Bhangar . It is characterized by slightly elevated terraces and is composed of older, more compact sediments compared to the newer and more fertile alluvial deposits found in the Khadar regions. The Bhangar area is less fertile due to the presence of calcareous deposits known as "Kankar."

questions.question: Which unit is used to measure the concentration of contaminants in soil and sediment?
questions.explanation: PPM (Parts per million) is commonly used to express very dilute concentrations of substances in various environmental contexts, including soil and sediment analysis.

questions.question: In which of the following processes nutrients or contaminants are carried away by water or moved into the lower layer of the soil ?
questions.explanation: Leaching: It occurs as excess water removes water-soluble nutrients out of the soil, by runoff or drainage. It is an environmental problem for agricultural professionals whether chemical-heavy fertilisers or chemicals are swept out and ﬁnd their way into water bodies.

questions.question: The black soil of the Deccan Plateau lacks which of the following minerals?
questions.explanation: Phosphor ous. Black soil is rich in Iron, lime, calcium, potassium, aluminum and magnesium and is deﬁ cient in Nitrogen and organic matter. Black soil or cotton soil is good for moisture and good for growing cotton, sugarcane, wheat, jawar, rice, citrus fruits, sun ﬂ ower, linseed, etc. Black soil requires minimum tillage because of its self-cultivating feature.

questions.question: Laterite soil develops as a result of which of the following reasons ?
questions.explanation: Leaching - It is used to extract the substances from the solids. Laterite Soil: It develops in areas with high temperature and high rainfall. These are the result of intense leaching due to tropical rains. It is commonly found in Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Madhya Pradesh and the hilly areas of Odisha and Assam.

topic: Laterite Soil is most suitable soil for growing coffee in India

questions.question: The black soil area of the _______ is known as the Deccan Trap.
questions.explanation: P eninsular Plateau. It is an ancient landmass composed mainly of igneous and metamorphic hard crystalline rocks. It was formed due to the breaking and drifting of Gondwanaland. Deccan Plateau - A triangular landmass that lies to the south of the river Narmada. Black Soil Covers most of the deccan plateau which includes part of Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Andhra Pradesh and some part of Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: In which of the following states of India is the maximum extent of alluvial soil found?
questions.explanation: Uttar Pr adesh. Alluvial Soil found in northern plains and the river valleys. It is rich in potash but poor in phosphorus. Two types of alluvial soil : Khadar - New alluvium, deposited by ﬂoods annually, which enriches the soil by depositing ﬁne slits. Bhangar - Old alluvium, deposited away from the ﬂood plains. Alluvial soils are intensively cultivated.

questions.question: What is the type of soil composedof silt and dust ?
questions.explanation: Loess. Properties : Colour - Yellowish Brown, Homogeneous and Highly Porous. Mostly Found (India) - Kashmir Valley. Loam - The type of Soil composed of sand, silt, and clay soil. Marl - The type of soil composed of Clays and Slit. Podsol - The soil derives from either quartz-rich sands and sandstone or sedimentary debris from magmatic rocks.

questions.question: The colour of the alluvial soils varies from ________.
questions.explanation: light gr e y t o ash gr e y . Alluvial soils are formed by the deposition of sediments from rivers and streams. These sediments are typically composed of sand, silt, and clay, which are all light-coloured materials. The colour of the alluvial soils can also be affected by the presence of organic matter, which can give them a darker colour. Light orange to dark orange is the colour of laterite soils. Orange to red is the colour of red soils.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of micronutrient supplied by soil ?
questions.explanation: Ir on. Soil is a major source of nutrients needed by plants for growth. Macronutrients in soil - Nitrogen (N), Phosphorus (P), Potassium (K), Calcium (Ca), Magnesium (Mg) and Sulphur (S). Micronutrients in soil - Chlorine (Cl), Boron (B), Iron (Fe), Manganese (Mn), Copper (Cu), Zinc (Zn), Nickel (Ni) and Molybdenum (Mo).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT correct regarding fertilizers ?

options.b: They are very rich in plant nutrients
options.c: They provide humus to the soil

questions.explanation: Humus is the organic component of soil that is formed by the decomposition of plant and animal matter. It can be produced naturally or through a process called composting. Manures are used to provide humus insoil.

questions.question: Arid soils are characteristically developed in ___________. which exhibit characteristic arid topography.
questions.explanation: W estern Rajasthan. In India, the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) has classi ﬁ ed soils into 8 categories. They are: Alluvial Soil, Black Cotton Soil, Red & Yellow Soil, Laterite Soil, Mountainous or Forest Soil, Arid or Desert Soil, Saline and Alkaline Soil, Peaty and Marshy Soil.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of 'soil - characteristics' is correct? I. Sandy - proportion of ﬁne particles is relatively higher II. Clayey - greater proportion of big particles
questions.explanation: Neither I nor II. Sandy Soil : Consists of small particles of weathered rock; One of the poorest types of soil for growing plants (very low nutrients and poor water holding capacity); Good for the drainage system; Usually formed by the breakdown or fragmentation of rocks like granite, limestone and quartz. Clay Soil : Smallest particles (tightly packed together with each other with very little or no airspace); Good water storage qualities; Very sticky to touch when wet but smooth when dried; Densest and heaviest type of soil which does not drain well or provide space for plant roots to ﬂourish.

questions.question: Which of the following factors of soil formation determines the accumulation of the soil ?
questions.explanation: Relief: Altitude and slope, determine accumulation of soil. Other Factors: Fauna is all of the animal life present in a particular region or time. Flora is all the plant life present in a particular region or time, generally the naturally occurring native plants.

questions.question: In which of the following soil conservation methods different crops are grown in alternate rows and are sown at different times to protect the soil from rain wash ?
questions.explanation: Inter cr opping. Its most common goal is to produce a greater yield on a given piece of land. Terrace farming - An agricultural practice where farmers employ on steep slopes, hilly areas, and higher altitudes. Contour ploughing - Process of cutting furrows into the slope of the land in order to control the ﬂow of water.

questions.question: In which of the soil conservation methods in the coastal and dry regions, rows of trees are planted to check the wind movement to protect soil cover?
questions.explanation: Shelterbelts. Mulching: The bare ground between plants is covered with a layer of organic matter like straw. It helps to retain soil moisture. Contour barriers: Stones, grass, soil are used to build barriers along contours. Trenches are made in front of the barriers to collect water.

questions.question: Identify the step that is NOT a part of decomposition.
questions.explanation: Soil er osion is the denudation or wearing away of the upper layer of soil. It is a form of soil degradation. There are ﬁv e steps of decomposition. These are fragmentation, leaching, catabolism, humi ﬁ cation, and mineralization.

questions.question: Which of the following factors does NOT affect the formation of soil?
questions.explanation: Landslides. Climate affects the soil due to temperature and rainfall. P ar ent material is the foundation of soil formation, different materials develop different soil types. T opogr aphy affects soil formation by in ﬂ uencing factors like drainage, erosion, and accumulation of sediments.

questions.question: What do you call the weight a soil can withstand before severe damage occurs to the structure of the soil?
questions.explanation: Bearing capacity is the capacity of soil to support the loads that are applied to the ground above. Field capacity is the amount of soil moisture or water content held in the soil after excess water has drained away and the rate of downward movement has decreased. Bulk density is de ﬁ ned as the mass of the many particles of the material divided by the total volume they occupy. Buff er capacity refers to the amount of acid or base a buffer can neutralise before the pH changes by a large amount.

questions.question: __________ develops on crystalline igneous rocks in areas of low rainfall in the eastern and southern part of the Deccan Plateau.
questions.explanation: Red soil. It contains a high percentage of iron content, which is responsible for its colour.

questions.question: Which part of the soil contains humus?
questions.explanation: A-horiz on. This layer is the top layer of soil which is also known as a humus layer and is mainly rich in organic materials. B-horiz on is typically a mineral subsurface horizon and is a zone of accumulation, called illuviation. C-horiz on : This soil layer lies beneath the B horizon and consists essentially of the more or less weathered parent rock. Bedr ock : Bedrock in geology is a solid rock that lies under loose softer material within the crust of Earth or another terrestrial planet.

questions.question: ___________ are thick deposits of glacial clay and other materials embedded with moraines.
questions.explanation: Kar ewas are lacustrine deposits (deposits in a lake) in the valley of Kashmir and in the Bhaderwah valley of the Jammu division of Jammu and Kashmir. These are the ﬂat-t opped mounds that border the Kashmir valley on all sides.

questions.question: _______ is a deep red soil found in tropical regions and often developed onmaﬁ c igneous bedrock.
questions.explanation: Laterite . Arid soils are formed from the fragmentation of adjacent rocks and are largely blown from the Indus valley area and coastal regions. Saline soils are formed whenever climate, soil, and hydrological conditions favor the accumulation of soluble salts in the root zone.

questions.question: As per ‘Soils of India, National Bureau of Soil Survey and Land Use Planning report: Publication Number 94’ which type of soil (order) is most abundantly available?
questions.explanation: Inceptisols: A soil order in USD A soil taxonomy. They form quickly through the alteration of the parent material. They are more developed than Entisols.

questions.question: Which of the following soils is found in areas of heavy rainfall and high humidity?
questions.explanation: P eaty soil or marshy soils are a result of waterlogging and anaerobic conditions. They are found in areas of heavy rainfall and high humidity, where there is a good growth of vegetation.

questions.question: In which year was the Soil Survey of India established to carry out scienti ﬁ c surveys of soils?
Robert has sandy soil in his ﬁelds. The ideal crop for his ﬁeld is:
questions.explanation: Gr am can be grown on a wide range of soil. But well drained medium to black cotton soils are very suitable. It can also be grown in light alluvial soils which are rich in organic matter.

questions.question: The process that moves, elevates or builds up portions of the earth’s crust is called:
questions.explanation: Diastr ophism. Denudation is the process of wearing away the Earth's surface by weathering and erosion. Volcanism is the process of molten rock (magma) erupting onto the Earth's surface.

questions.question: The Ebony, Mahogany, Cinchona etc. are trees found in which type of forests in India?
questions.explanation: T r opical E v er gr een F or ests are restricted to heavy rainfall areas of the Western Ghats and the island groups of Lakshadweep, Andaman and Nicobar, upper parts of Assam and Tamil Nadu coast. Other trees are rosewood, and rubber. Tropical Deciduous Forests - Teak, Bamboos, sal, shisham. Thorny Forests - Acacias, palms, euphorbias and cacti. Mangrove Forests - Sundari trees, Palm, Coconut.

questions.question: Magnolia and Laurel trees are found in which type of forest in India?
questions.explanation: Montane F or ests. In mountainous areas, temperature decreases with altitude, leading to a change in vegetation. Between 1000–2000 meters, wet temperate forests with evergreen broad-leaf trees like oaks and chestnuts are found. Between 1500–3000 meters, coniferous trees such as pine, deodar, and cedar dominate, mainly on the southern slopes of the Himalayas. Higher elevations feature temperate grasslands, and above 3600 meters, alpine vegetation takes over with trees like silver ﬁr , junipers, and pines.

questions.question: ________ leaves are used to make bidis.
questions.explanation: T endu tree (Diospyros melanoxylon Roxb.) belonging to Family Ebenaceae.Q.409 . Sundari trees are found in which type of forests in India? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Mangrove forests (b) Tropical deciduous forests (c) The thorn forests and scrubs (d) Tropical evergreen forests Sol.409.(a) Mangr o v e for ests. Sundari tree is the most abundant tree in the mangrove forests of the Sunderban delta in West Bengal and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. The Sunderbans are named after the Sundari tree. Mangrove forests grow only at tropical and subtropical latitudes near the equator because they cannot withstand freezing temperatures. Uppu ponna, Boddu ponna, Urada, Mada, Telli Mada, Gundu mada, Kadili, Palm, coconut, keora, agar and Bella are some of the typical vegetation of the mangroves.

questions.question: Which of the following states has mangrove forests?
questions.explanation: A ndhr a Pr adesh. Mangroves are practically evergreen with thick leathery leaves. Such types of forests are found in the deltas of Sundarbans, Mahanadi, the Godavari, Krishna, Kaveri rivers and in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

questions.question: In which of the following regions is the tropical evergreen forests found in India?
questions.explanation: W estern Ghats. Tropical evergreen forests are found on the western slopes of the Western Ghats, northeastern hills, and Andaman and Nicobar Islands. They thrive in warm, humid areas with over 200 cm of annual rainfall and temperatures above 22°C. These forests are dense, with tall trees reaching up to 60 meters and remain green year-round. Common species include rosewood, mahogany, and ebony.

questions.question: In which of the following parts of India are thorn forests and scrub forests found?
questions.explanation: Nor th-western India. Thornand scrub forests are a type of natural vegetation found in regions that receive less than 70 cm of annual rainfall. These regions typically experience dry and arid climatic conditions, and the vegetation here has adapted to conserve water and withstand harsh environments. It is found in parts of northwestern India, central Deccan Plateau, and parts of the Thar Desert. The main plant species include Acacia (Babool), Cactus, Euphorbias, and Palms.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT true about the moist deciduous forests of India?

options.a: They grow in regions with rainfall of 100-200 cm.
options.b: They are found in the foothills of Himalayas.
options.c: They are found in the plains of Bihar and Uttar Pradesh.
options.d: Sal, amla, shisham and mahua are some of the main species of these forests.

questions.explanation: Moist deciduous forests exist mostly in the eastern part of the country – northeastern states, along the foothills of the Himalayas, Jharkhand, West Odisha and Chhattisgarh, and on the eastern slopes of the Western Ghats. The dry deciduous forests are found in areas having rainfall between 100 cm and 70 cm. These forests are found in the rainier parts of the Peninsular plateau and the plains of Bihar and Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: In the Himalayas, the ________ temperature with increasing altitude causes the change in vegetation.
questions.explanation: decr easing. The Himala y an r anges show change in vegetation from tropical to tundra. Since air is less dense at higher altitudes, its molecules are spread farther apart than they are at sea level. These molecules have fewer collisions, so they produce less heat. At the bottom of the mountain, the temperature is high year-round while it is much cooler at the top due to which it is covered with snow.

questions.question: Under which strata do trees fall ?
questions.explanation: T op v er tical. Str ata are layers of vegetation that are de ﬁ ned by the height of the plants. Second v er tical - It contains the second-tallest plants in a forest ecosystem, such as shrubs and small trees. Bott om v er tical - It contains the shortest plants in a forest ecosystem, such as mosses and ferns. Middle v er tical - It contains the plants that are in between the top and bottom vertical strata, such as medium-sized shrubs and trees.

questions.question: The natural vegetation of India is broadly divided into ______ groups.
questions.explanation: 5. Vegetation of India – Tropical evergreen forest, Tropical deciduous forest, Thorny bushes, Mountain vegetation and Mangrove forests.

questions.question: In which type of forests are wild donkeys and camels found in India?
questions.explanation: Thorny for ests and bushes. Animals found in different forests in India: Tropical Evergreen Forests - Elephants, Monkeys, Lemurs and Deer. Montane Forests - Leopard, Yak, Sheep and Goat. Mangrove forest - Royal Bengal Tiger. In terms of area, Madhya Pradesh has the largest forest area in the country. It is followed by Arunachal Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha and Maharashtra.

questions.question: Sal, acacia and bamboo, which are types of Dry Tropical Forest, receive what amount of annual rainfall?
questions.explanation: F r om 51 cm t o 151 cm. T r opical for ests (rainforests) : A rainforest is an area of tall, mostly evergreen trees and a high amount of rainfall, Earth’s oldest living ecosystems, with some surviving in their present form for at least 70 million years. T ypes of T r opical for ests - Evergreen Rain (200 cm or more), Monsoon Deciduous (100 to 200 cm), Tropical Savanna (50 to 100 cm), Dry Thorny Scrub (Semi-arid) (25 to 50 cm), Desert (Arid) (Below 25 cm).

questions.question: Which of the following forest types is found on the foothills of theHimalayas?
questions.explanation: Deciduous. This is an evergreen forest where a majority of the trees remain “green” throughout the year because they shed leaves not seasonally but at various periods of the year. Example - Maple, oak, and elm. T emper ate - Forest found between the tropical and boreal regions, located in the temperate zone. Example - Fir, oak. T undr a - Found in the Arctic and on the tops of mountains, where the climate is cold and windy, and rainfall is scant. Example - Arctic Willow. Alpine - Occur all along the Himalayas at altitudes ranging between 2,900 to 3,500 m. Example - Spruce and birch.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most widespread forest type in India?
questions.explanation: T r opical Deciduous F or ests (Monsoon Forests): It Found in India along the Equator belt between the tropic of Cancer and the tropic of Capricorn, (Major states - Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Odisha, Some Parts of Maharashtra).

questions.question: What type of vegetation is found in the plateau of Meghalaya, Sahyadri and the central and southern islands of the Nicobar group?
questions.explanation: Moist T r opical Semi - E v er gr een V egetation are transitional forests between tropical wet evergreen forests and tropical deciduous forests. Examples - Laurel, rosewood, mesua, white cedar. Tropical Dry Deciduous Vegetation - Occurs in an irregular wide strip running from the foot of the Himalayas to Kanyakumari except in Rajasthan, Western Ghats and West Bengal. Example - Teak, bamboo. Tropical Thorn Forests - Found in Rajasthan, south-western Punjab, western Haryana, Kachchh and neighbouring parts of Saurashtra. Example - Babool, neem, cactii.Q.422. Plant varieties like bamboo, epiphytes, aini, semul, gutel and mundane are found in which type of Indian forest? SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (2nd shift) (a) Alpine forest (b) Montane temperate forest (c) Moist tropical forest (d) Dry tropical forest Sol.422.(c) Moist tr opical for ests have 200-250 cm annual rainfall, 24-27°C temperature. Alpine for est - Common in both the main Himalayan regions as well as the barren cold deserts of the Trans Himalaya. Examples - Black juniper and willow. Montane temper ate for est - Mainly generated in Northern middle Himalayas ranges (1801 to 3001 m) and Southern Niligiri higher Mountain ranges. Examples - Ferns, oak and maple. Dr y tr opical for est - Mainly found in Indian Northern Hilly regions and some states of Southern India. Examples - Sal, acacia, mangoes.

questions.question: Which of the following states is associated with the tropical thorn forests?
questions.explanation: Madhy a Pr adesh. Tropical Thorn Forests and Scrubs (receive rainfall less than 50 cm) -It includes semi - arid areas of south west Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh. Trees like – Babool, ber, wild date palm, Khair tree.

questions.question: Mosses and lichens are found in which kind of forest?
questions.explanation: T undr a F or est - It has relatively little rain and extremely cold temperatures. It is composed of dwarf shrubs, sedges, and grasses.

questions.question: Major plantations are found in the __________ region of the world.
questions.explanation: T r opical. Plantation cr ops - A type of commercial farming where a single crop of tea, coffee, sugarcane, cashew, rubber, banana or cotton are grown. Major plantations - Rubber in Malaysia, coffee in Brazil, tea in India and Sri Lanka. Major food cr ops - Wheat, rice, maize and millets. Jute and cotton are ﬁ br e cr ops.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a terrestrial ecosystem?
questions.explanation: Gr asslands. T err estrial ecosystem - It is a land-based community of species that includes biotic and abiotic interactions in a speci ﬁ c area. Examples - Forest, Grasslands, Tundra, Desert. Aquatic ecosystem - It is related to water. It includes Freshwater ecosystem (Pond, lake, river) and Marine ecosystem (Ocean, sea or estuary). K elp is a type of large, brown seaweed that grows in shallow, nutrient-rich saltwater near coastal fronts around the world.

questions.question: In the higher latitudes (50° - 70°) of Northern hemisphere the spectacular Coniferous forests are found. These are also called as ______ .
questions.explanation: T aiga - Trees found are mainly cone-bearing trees like spruce, pine, ﬁr , and hemlock. V eld - Open, uncultivated country or grassland in southern Africa. T undr a - A vast, ﬂat, tr eeless Arctic region of Europe, Asia, and North America in which the subsoil is permanently frozen. Llanos - A vast tropical grassland plain situated to the east of the Andes in Colombia and Venezuela, in northwestern South America.

questions.question: In India, trees of which forest type shed their leaves for about six to eight weeks in dry summer?
questions.explanation: T r opical Deciduous F or ests. These forests spread over regions which receive rainfall between 70-200 cm. Tendu, palas, amaltas, bel, khair, axlewood, etc are the common trees of these forests.

questions.question: In India, what is the mean annual average temperature in subtropical vegetation zone ?
questions.explanation: 17°C t o 24°C. Natural vegetation - The plant life that grows in an area without the in ﬂ uence of human activity. Types - Forests, Grasslands (divided into savannas, steppes and prairies, depending on the climate and other environmental factors), Deserts (These are arid regions with very little rainfall and sparse vegetation), Tundra (This is a cold, treeless region found in the Arctic and on high mountain slopes), Wetland (These are areas with water-logged soil, such as marshes).

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of countries - name of grassland is correct? I. Argentina - Pampas, II. Brazil - Steppe
questions.explanation: Only I. Steppe - Europe and North Asia, Brazil - Campos, Pustaz- Hungary, Prairies - USA, Veld - South Africa, Downs - Australia, Canterbury - New Zealand, Savannah - Africa, Taiga - Europe and Asia.

questions.question: The wet temperate type of forests are found between a height of _______ metres.
questions.explanation: 1000 and 2000. W et temper ate for ests: Average annual rainfall and temperature in wet temperate forests are 150-300 cm and 11°C-14°C respectively. The relative humidity is over 80% on average. Oak trees and chestnut trees are found here. Other important species include Chilauni, Indian chestnut, Deodar, Machilus, Cinnamomum, Litsea, Plum, Blue pine, Birch, Oak, Hemlock, etc.

questions.question: Thorny bushes are found in _____ region.
questions.explanation: dr y deser t. In areas where there is less than 70 cm of rainfall ,thorn forests and shrubs are found in the natural vegetation. This type of vegetation is found in the north-western parts of the country, which include the semi-arid regions of Gujarat, Rajasthan, Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh and Haryana.

questions.question: The type of forests located in midlatitudinal coastal region is__________
questions.explanation: T emper ate e v er gr een for ests. They are commonly found on the eastern edges of continents, such as in southeastern America, southern China, and southeastern Brazil. T r opical r ainfor ests are mainly located in the tropics, between the latitudes of 23.5°N (the Tropic of Cancer) and 23.5°S (the Tropic of Capricorn)—the tropics.

questions.question: The birds like pheasant and monals are found in which type of forest?
questions.explanation: T emper ate deciduous for est. As we go towards higher latitudes, there are more temperate deciduous forests. These are found in the north eastern part of the USA, China, New Zealand, Chile and also found in the coastal regions of Western Europe. They shed their leaves in the dry season. Common trees include oak, ash, and beech. Animals commonly found in these forests are deer, foxes, and wolves.

questions.question: A species of grass named ______ is on the verge of extinction due to its insensitivity towards the environment.
questions.explanation: Hubbar dia heptaneur on. The native range of this species is India (Karnataka). It is an annual and grows primarily in the seasonally dry tropical biome. Helianthus annuus (Common Sunﬂ ower).

questions.question: The National Commission on Agriculture (1976) of India has classi ﬁ ed social forestry into how many categories?
questions.explanation: 3. Social forestry means the management and protection of forests and afforestation on barren lands with the purpose of helping in the environmental, social and rural development. Three categories are Urban forestry, Rural forestry and Farm forestry.

questions.question: Which biome is found in the northern parts of Asia, Europe and North America where 300 to 900 millimeters (12 to 35 in) of rain can be expected per year?
questions.explanation: Conif er ous for est (composed primarily of cone-bearing needle-leaved or scale-leaved evergreen trees, Pines, spruces, ﬁrs, and larches are the dominant trees in coniferous forests).

questions.question: The climatic conditions of thorn forests and scrubs are the most ideal for which of the following plant species?
questions.explanation: E uphorbia. It is a perennial herb that grows to 30 cm tall in the dry grasslands of Siberia, Mongolia, China, Korea, and Japan.

questions.question: Temperate grasslands are ideal for _______ cultivation.
questions.explanation: wheat . Viticulture or grape cultivation is a speciality of the Mediterranean region. Grapes are cultivated on a very wide range of soils from gravelly sands to clays that can be of high or poor fertility.

questions.question: Which of the following is a temperate grassland in Russia?
questions.explanation: Steppes. T emper ate gr asslands have cold winters and warm summers with some rain. Examples include Eurasian steppes, North American prairies and Argentine pampas.

questions.question: What type of forests are found north and south of the equator between 40° and 60° where rainfall is high, between 500-1500 mm in a year?
questions.explanation: T emper ate deciduous for ests.

questions.question: Which type of biome is located in Eastern North America, Western Europe, and Northeast Asia?
questions.explanation: Deciduous F or est Biomes - This biome experiences all four seasons, these forests are divided into ﬁ v e z ones based on the heights of the trees. The soil is particularly fertile and nutrient-rich and is located in North America (Canada, the United States, and Mexico), Europe, and western regions of Asia (Japan, China, North Korea, South Korea, and parts of Russia).

questions.question: Which of the following statements about forests is INCORRECT?

options.a: In a forest, trees form the uppermost layer of vegetation.
options.b: Forests protect the soil from erosion.
options.c: In a forest, shrubs form the lowest layer of vegetation.
options.d: Forests in ﬂ uence climate, water cycle and air quality.

questions.explanation: The layer of vegetation in the forest which is just below the shrub layer is called the herb layer. The herb layer consists mainly of herbs, ferns and grasses. This layer is the lowest layer of vegetation in the forest (having leafy plants). Very little sunlight remains for the plants in the herb layer.

questions.question: Coringa is a beautiful _____ forest where the Godavari joins the backwaters of Bay of Bengal.
questions.explanation: Mangr o v e. Coringa is the second largest mangrove formation in India, next to Sundarbans. The Coringa mangroves are bordered on the northern side by Kakinada Bay. Q.445 . Which of the following trees will youﬁnd in the Littoral forests? SSC CHSL 19/10/2020(Afternoon) (a) Chinar (b) Ebony (c) Sundari (d) Cypress Sol.445.(c) Sundari tree is found in Sundarbans delta in West Bengal in Mangrove forest (Littoral forests).

questions.question: Tropical cyclones originate over which of the following regions?

options.a: Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea and the Indian Ocean
options.b: Mediterranean Sea, Paci ﬁ c Ocean and the Indian Ocean
options.c: Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea and the Atlantic Ocean
options.d: Mediterranean Sea, Arabian Sea and the Indian Ocean

questions.explanation: A tropical cyclone is formed over warm ocean waters near the equator. The centre of a cyclone is very calm and clear with very low air pressure. The average speed is 120 kmph. They move from east to west under the inﬂ uence of trade winds.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding orographic rainfall is correct?

options.a: It occurs mainly during summer and is common over equatorial doldrums in theCongo basin.
options.b: This type of precipitation occurs when warm, humid air strikes on a mountain range.
options.c: This precipitation is heavy but of short duration, highly localised and is associated with minimum amount of cloudiness.
options.d: This type of precipitation is characterised by seasonal reversal of winds that carry oceanic moisture.

questions.explanation: Or ogr aphic r ainfall occurs when moist air hits a mountain and is forced to rise. As the air ascends, it cools, leading to condensation and saturation. The excess moisture then falls as precipitation on the windward slopes.

questions.question: The climatic diversity of India is characterised by its distinctiveness, and one of the following factors does NOT contribute to it is ___________.
questions.explanation: The latitudinal extent inﬂ uences temperature and rainfall patterns due to variations in solar energy and atmospheric density. However, it is not a major factor contributing to India's climatic diversity compared to longitudinal extent, topography, and vegetation.

questions.question: Which state lies in the rain shadow region of the Arabian Sea branch of the southwest monsoon?
questions.explanation: T amil Nadu. The Bay of Bengal monsoon branch strikes Myanmar and southeast Bangladesh, but the Arakan Hills de ﬂ ect much of it towards India. It enters West Bengal and Bangladesh from the south - southeast, splitting into two branches. One moves westward along the Ganga plains to the Punjab plains, while the other ascends the Brahmaputra valley, causing rains in the northeast. A sub-branch hits Meghalaya's Khasi hills. The Tamil Nadu coast remains dry as it lies parallel to the Bay of Bengal monsoon branch and in the rain-shadow region of the Arabian Sea branch.

questions.question: In which part of India does the hot wind ‘Loo’ blow?
questions.explanation: Nor th and Nor thwestern. Loo - These are strong, gusty, hot, dry winds blowing during the day over the north and northwestern India. In West Bengal, similar storms are known as ‘Kaal Baisakhi’. They blow in the summer season. Other hot winds - Foehn (Europe), Chinook (USA), Santa Ana (USA), Sirocco (North Africa and South Europe), Harmattan (Guinea coast), Khamsin (Egypt).

questions.question: The climate of a place is NOT affected by which of the following?
questions.explanation: T ype of soil. Climate refers to the long-term conditions of a speci ﬁ c region. The changes in climate within a region are in ﬂ uenced by its atmospheric and environmental conditions. The six major factors that in ﬂ uence the climate of a location are latitude, altitude, pressure, and wind systems, distance from the sea (continentality), ocean currents, and relief features.

questions.question: Which region in India receivesless rainfall in summer, but heavy rainfall in winter season due to the retreating north easterly winds?
questions.explanation: Eastern coastal r egion stretches from West Bengal in the north to Tamil Nadu in the south and passes through Andhra Pradesh and Odisha. The retreating or North-East monsoon brings heavy rainfall to the Coromandel coast from October to December. This monsoon, blowing from land to sea, gathers moisture and causes rain, making it the primary rainy season for southeastern India, including Tamil Nadu. The Coromandel coast lies between Pulicat Lake and Kanyakumari.

questions.question: Which is the colloquial term to describe the occurrence of pre-monsoon rains in India especially in parts of Kerala, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu?
questions.explanation: Mango showers. These are pre-monsoon rains that occur at the end of the summer season, helping the mangoes ripen; These are also called April rains.

questions.question: The tropical cyclones in Australia are known as ________.
questions.explanation: willy-willies. Tropical cyclones are intense low-pressure areas that form in the atmosphere between 30° N and 30° S latitudes. They can extend up to 1,000 km horizontally and 12–14 km vertically from the surface. Tropical cyclones rotate counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere and clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. Their names in different countries : Hurricanes - United States, Typhoons - China Sea and Paci ﬁ c Ocean, Cyclones - Indian Ocean.

questions.question: What is the duration of monsoon in India?
questions.explanation: 100-120 da ys. The monsoon season in India lasts from June to September. The southwest monsoon (summer monsoon) brings the majorityof annual rainfall, blowing from the sea to land across the Indian Ocean, Arabian Sea, and Bay of Bengal. In contrast, the northeast monsoon (winter monsoon) blows from land to sea.

questions.question: Which of the following group of months is the coldest in North India?
questions.explanation: In December and January, temperatures decrease from south to north, with the Northern Plains averaging 10°C to 15°C, while Chennai on the eastern coast sees averages of 24°C to 25°C. Days are warm, and nights are cold during this period.

questions.question: Which of the following parts of the mountain will receive the most rainfall from moisture-laden winds?
questions.explanation: Windwar d side - The on-shore moisture laden winds are forced to rise after striking against the mountains and give heavy rainfall on the windward side. Leeward side - It receives little to no rainfall and is known as the rain shadow area. Orographic rainfall occurs when saturated air mass comes across a mountain.

questions.question: Which theory describes the collective effects of changes in Earth's movements on its climate over thousands of years?
questions.explanation: Milanko vitch theor y . Copernican heliocentrism, proposed by Copernicus in 1543, positions the Sun at the center, with Earth and other planets orbiting it. Plate tectonics is a scienti ﬁ c theory that explains how major landforms are created as a result of Earth's subterranean movements.

questions.question: Which of the following groups of places in India has little differences in day and night temperatures?
questions.explanation: Chennai and Thiruv ananthapur am. Thar desert experiences the highest diurnal range of temperature. This is because of the fact that sand (found in ample quantity in this region) gains and loses heat very quickly. As a result of this phenomenon, there is a wide difference between day and night temperatures in this region. The day temperature may rise to 50°C and drop down to near 15°C the same night. There is no sea closer to this area and hence there is no moderating effect.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about climate is INCORRECT?

options.a: India’s climate has characteristics of tropical as well as subtropical climates.
options.b: Coastal areas of India experience less contrasts in temperature conditions as compared to the interior of the country.
options.c: ‘Monsoon’ type of climate is found mainly in south and southeast Asia.
options.d: India experiences comparatively stronger winters as compared to central Asia.

questions.explanation: Central Asia generally experiences stronger winters compared to India due to its continental location and lack of moderating in ﬂ uences like large bodies of water. The Climate of India is the tropical monsoon climate type with regional variations in temperature, precipitation, and amount of rainfall because of the large geographical area.

questions.question: Western disturbances are responsible for:

options.a: dusty storms in eastern coastal area of India
options.b: hot winds during summers in northern India
options.c: extremely chilled weather of north - east India
options.d: rainfall during winters in north - western part of India

questions.explanation: The western cyclonic disturbances which enter the Indian subcontinent from the west and the northwest during the winter months, originate over the Mediterranean Sea and are brought into India by the westerly jet stream.

questions.question: According to Koeppen's Scheme of classi ﬁ cation of climate, which of thefollowing characteristics is associated with 'Group E' ?

options.a: The average temperature of the coldest month is –3°C or below
options.b: The average temperature for all months is below 10°C
options.c: The average temperature of the coldest month is higher than –3°C but below 18°C
options.d: The average temperature of the coldest month is 18°C or higher

questions.explanation: Climatic Groups According to Koeppen: A - Tropical: Average temperature of the coldest month is 18° C or higher. B - Dry Climates: Potential evaporation exceeds precipitation. C - Warm Temperate: The average temperature of the coldest month of the (Mid-latitude) climates is higher than minus 3°C but below 18°C. D - Cold Snow Forest Climates: The average temperature of the coldest month is minus 3° C or below. H - High Land: Cold due to elevation.

questions.question: El Nino is a climate pattern that describes the unusual warming of surface waters in which ocean?
questions.explanation: P aci ﬁ c Ocean. El Nino is a complex weather system that occurs every 3-7 years, causing droughts, ﬂoods, and extreme weather globally. It involves warm ocean currents off Peru's coast in the Eastern Paci ﬁ c, affecting various regions, including India. El Nino is an extension of the warm equatorial current that temporarily replaces the cold Humboldt (Peruvian) Current, increasing water temperatures by 10°C.

questions.question: In the context of local storms of hot weather season, Nor'Westers are:

options.a: the pre-monsoon showers that are a common phenomenon in Kerala and coastal areas of Karnataka
options.b: the dreaded evening thunderstorms in Bengal and Assam
options.c: the hot, dry and oppressing winds blowing in the Northern plains from Punjab to Bihar with higher intensity between Delhi and Patna
options.d: a nearby wind that blows coffee ﬂowers in Kerala

questions.explanation: Nor Westers : Their notorious nature can be understood from the local nomenclature of ‘Kalbaisakhi’, a calamity of the month of Baisakh. These showersare useful for tea, jute and rice cultivation. In Assam, these storms are known as “Bardoli Chheerha”. Some Famous Local Storms: Blossom Shower: Useful for coffee ﬂowers blooming in Kerala. Loo : Hot, dry and oppressing winds blowing in the Northern plains.

questions.question: Which of the following States/Union Territories of India receives the highest average annual rainfall ?
questions.explanation: Meghala y a. The maximum rainfall of this season is received in the north-eastern part of the country. Mawsynram in the southern ranges of the Khasi Hills receives the highest average rainfall in the world. Mawsynram, the wettest place on the earth is also reputed for its stalagmite and stalactite caves. Rainfall in the Ganga valley decreases from the east to the west. Rajasthan and parts of Gujarat get scanty rainfall.

questions.question: One term for the continuous movement of water through the lithosphere, atmosphere and hydrosphere is:
questions.explanation: hy dr ological cy cle. Components of the Hydrological Cycle : Evaporation - Water changes from liquid to gas, primarily from bodies of water.

questions.question: Identify a type of season that is NOT a part of the four seasons of India.
questions.explanation: The southeast monsoon season. Four main seasons can be identi ﬁ ed in India : The hot weather season (March to May), The southwest monsoon season (June to September), The post - monsoon or retreating monsoon season (October to December), The cold weather season (January to February).

questions.question: What is the name of the cold phase of the ENSO climate pattern that describes the unusual cooling of the surface waters of the region ?
questions.explanation: La Nina. In La Nina, the tropical Paci ﬁ c trade winds become very strong and an abnormal accumulation of cold water occurs in the central and eastern Paci ﬁ c Ocean. El Nino is a climate pattern that describes the unusual warming of surface waters in the eastern tropical Paci ﬁ c Ocean. El Nino is the “warm phase” of a larger phenomenon called the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO).

questions.question: Sea ice helps determine Earth's climate. According to this, what percentage of the sunlight falling on sea ice is re ﬂ ected back into space ?
questions.explanation: 80%. Sea ice re ﬂ ects a signi ﬁ cant portion of sunlight, which is essential for regulating Earth’s temperature. As sea ice diminishes, more solar energy is absorbed by the ocean, resulting in higher temperatures. This change affects global climate patterns and contributes to the acceleration of climate change. Albedo is the percentage of solar radiation re ﬂ ected by a given surface.

questions.question: Who is best known for his testimony on climate change to congressional committees in the 1980s, which helped raise wider awareness of the global warming issue?
questions.explanation: James Hansen. He is referred to as the “father of global warming” because of his early warnings about the phenomenon in the 1980s.

questions.question: According to the Koppen climate classi ﬁ cation system, ‘Am’ is the code for which type of climate?
questions.explanation: T r opical monsoon climate. Koeppen’s Classi ﬁ cation of Climatic Regions of India is based on mean annual and monthly temperature and precipitation data. He identi ﬁ ed ﬁv e major climatic groups: four based on temperature (A, C, D, E for humid climates) and one on precipitation (B for dry climates). These groups are furtherdivided into types, indicated by small letters that describe seasonality: f (no dry season), m (monsoon), w (winter dry), and s (summer dry). Climatic Regions of India: Amw, As, Aw, BShw, BWhw, Cwg, Dfc, Et, E.

questions.question: How many controls are there globally that in ﬂ uence the climate of a particular zone?
questions.explanation: 6. There are six major controls of the climate of any place. They are: latitude, altitude, pressure and wind system, distance from the sea (continentality), ocean currents and relief features.

questions.question: When was the Indian Meteorological Department, which collects data on temperature, rainfall, wind, etc., and makes weather forecasts, established by the Government of India?
questions.explanation: 1875. Indian Meteorological Department - An agency of the Ministry of Earth Sciences of the Government of India. It is the principal agency responsible for meteorological observations, weather forecasting and seismology. Formed - 15 January 1875. Headquarters - New Delhi. Regional oﬃ ces - Chennai, Mumbai, Kolkata, Nagpur, Guwahati and New Delhi.

questions.question: Choose the INCORRECT statement related to monsoon.

options.a: The intensity and position of the high-pressure area, east of Madagascar, affects the Indian Monsoon
options.b: The Southwest Monsoon winds blow over the warm oceans, gather moisture and bring widespread rainfall over the mainland of India.
options.c: The difference in pressure over Tahiti (Paci ﬁ c Ocean), and Darwin in northern Australia (Indian Ocean) is computed to predict the intensity of the monsoons.
options.d: The western cyclonic disturbances occur due to withdrawal or the retreat of the monsoon

questions.explanation: Western Cyclonic Disturbances are weather phenomena of the winter months brought in by the westerly ﬂow from the Mediterranean region. They usually in ﬂ uence the weather of the north and north-western regions of India. It originates over theMediterranean: The region which includes the Mediterranean Sea and seven Member States, either partially (France, Portugal, Italy, Spain) or completely (Greece, Malta, Cyprus).

questions.question: Which winds blow across the Asian continent at latitudes north of the Himalayas roughly parallel to the Tibetan highlands ?
questions.explanation: Jet str eams - A narrow belt of high altitude (above 12,000 m) westerly winds in the Troposphere. Their speed varies from about 110 km/h in summer to about 184 km/h in winter. The polar jet is located between the 50°-60° latitude lines in both the northern and southern hemispheres. The subtropical jet is located around the 30° latitude line.

questions.question: What type of climate is found in North Western Europe, West Coast of North America, North of California, Southern Chile, South-eastern Australia and New Zealand?
questions.explanation: Marine west coast climate - Under the Koppen Climate Classi ﬁ cation, it comes under Warm Temperate (Mid-Latitude) Climates (Group C) and is represented by ‘Cfb’.

questions.question: Choose the INCORRECT statement out of the following.

options.a: There is an increase in rainfall generally from east to west in the Northern Plains.
options.b: Most parts of the country receive rainfall from June to September.
options.c: The annual precipitation in Meghalaya is over 400 cm.
options.d: Some parts like the Tamil Nadu’s coast gets a large portion of its rains during October and November.

questions.explanation: Rainfall decreases from the east to the west in Northern India because there is a decrease in the moisture content of the winds. The monsoon approaches the Indian landmass in two branches: The Arabian Sea branch (The monsoon winds originating over the Arabian Sea) and the Bay of Bengal branch.

questions.question: In which type of rainfall, winds move out from a high-pressure area with wind direction clockwise in the northern hemisphere, and anti-clockwise in the southern hemisphere ?
questions.explanation: A nticy clone - It is the center of high pressure, surrounded by closed isobars. Due to Coriolis force, blowing winds are de ﬂ ected from their paths to the right in the Northern hemisphere (Clockwise) and left in the Southern hemisphere (Anti clockwise). Cyclones that develop in the mid and high latitudes, beyond the tropical regions, are referred to as middle latitude or extratropical cyclones.

questions.question: According to the Koppen classi ﬁ cation, Which regions experience cold humid winters with short summers?
questions.explanation: Arunachal Pr adesh. Koeppen identi ﬁ ed a close relationship between the distribution of vegetation and climate.

questions.question: What is the usual term used to describe the climate of India ?
questions.explanation: T r opical monsoon . A monsoon is a seasonal change in the direction of the prevailing, or strongest, winds of a region. It always blows from cold to warm regions. The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) designates four o ﬃ cial seasons: Winter (December to early April); Summer or pre-monsoon (April to June); Monsoon or rainy (June to September) and Post-monsoon (October to December).

questions.question: What is 'Mahawat' in India ?

options.a: Cold waves during the winter season
options.b: Cloud burst during the monsoon season
options.c: Cyclonic rainfall during the winter season
options.d: Hot and dry winds during the summer season

questions.explanation: Mahawat is the total amount of rainfall in the cold weather season, that is the winter season which is caused by the western cyclonic disturbances inthe north and north -western part of India.

questions.question: The target for the ﬁrst commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol is to reduce emissions of greenhouse gasses by 5.2% from 1990 levels?
questions.explanation: 6. Kyoto Protocol: It was adopted on 11 December 1997 and entered into force on 16 February 2005. It was adopted in Kyoto, Japan. It was the result of the Rio-1992 and the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Kyoto Protocol cover emissions of the six main greenhouse gases Carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH 4), nitrous oxide (N 2O), hydro ﬂ uorocarbons (HFCs), perﬂ uorocarbons (PFCs), and sulfur hexa ﬂ uoride (SF 6).

questions.question: In the context of mapping climate data, what term refers to a line drawn through all points on a map that contain the same amount of cloud?
questions.explanation: Isonephs. Isocheim - A line on a map connecting points having the same average temperature in winter. Isohel - A line on a map connecting points having the same duration of sunshine. Isochalaz - A line of constant frequency of hail storms.

questions.question: According to Koeppen's Scheme, which type of climate is denoted by 'Cwg' in India?
questions.explanation: Monsoon with dr y winter - It is mostly found in the Ganga Plain, eastern Rajasthan, Assam, and the Malwa Plateau. Amw (Monsoon type with a short dry winter season): This climate is found in the western coastal region, south of Mumbai.

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrectly matched?

options.a: Montane climate - Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Jharkhand
options.b: Tropical monsoon climate - The Western Ghats, the Malabar Coast And Southern Assam
options.c: Tropical semi-arid (steppe) climate - Karnataka, central Maharashtra, some parts of Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh
options.d: Hot desserts, arid climate - rajasthan and some parts of Gujarat

questions.explanation: Montane climate - Found in Assam, Nagaland, Mizoram, Meghalaya, Manipur, Arunachal Pradesh, Higher hills of Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: The centre of a cyclone is a calm area. It is called the_______of the storm.
questions.explanation: E y e. The eye of a storm is usually circular and typically 25-40 miles in diameter. It is surrounded by an eyewall, where the most severe weather of a cyclone occurs.

questions.question: What would happen if the difference in pressure in Tahiti was negative?
questions.explanation: The difference in pressure over Tahiti (Paci ﬁ c Ocean) and Darwin in Northern Australia (Indian Ocean) is computed to predict the intensity of the monsoons. Factors Affecting Monsoon - The shift of the position of Inter Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ); The presence of the high-pressure area, east of Madagascar; Heating of The Tibetan plateau in summers; The movement of the jet streams; Southern Oscillation (SO) - Change of pressure between south Paci ﬁ c Ocean and eastern Indian Ocean.

questions.question: What type of climate occurs along the west coast of continents in subtropical latitudes between 30°-40° latitudes, covering Central California, Central Chile along the coast in South East and South Western Australia?
questions.explanation: Mediterr anean climate: Clear skies and high temperatures; hot, dry summers and cool, wet winters. The climate is not extreme because of cooling from water bodies. This unique seasonal pattern makes it ideal for growing crops like olives, grapes, and citrus fruits.

questions.question: What is the average temperature usually in the hills of the western ghats?
questions.explanation: Below 25°C. Western Ghats - These are also known as the Sahyadri Hills. It covers six states - Gujarat, Maharashtra, Goa, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, and Kerala.

questions.question: Which winds are also known by the name of 'Roaring Forties' ?
questions.explanation: W esterly Wind. The polar easterlies are one of the ﬁv e primary wind zones, known as wind belts, that make up our atmosphere's circulatory system. Polar winds begin near the North and South Poles. The trade winds are air currents closer to Earth's surface that blow from east to west near the equator.

questions.question: Which among the following wind is associated with extreme cold and dryness?
questions.explanation: P olar Easterlies . They emanate from the polar highs, areas of high pressure around the North and South Poles. They ﬂow to low-pressure areas in sub-polar regions. Easterlies (blow from the east) - It is the name of the permanent winds that come from the direction of their origin. Monsoon Winds - They are caused when the air over land gets heated and rises, causing winds to blow from the ocean toward land. Westerlies - Prevailing winds from the west toward the east in the middle latitudes.

questions.question: The summer months experience __________ in the northern part of India.
questions.explanation: F alling air pr essur e. An elongated low-pressure area develops in the region extending from the Thar Desert in the northwest to Patna and Chotanagpur plateau in the east and southeast towards the end of May. Circulation of air begins to set in aroundthis trough. InterTropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) - Low pressure region around which the southeast trade winds and the northeast trade winds converge.

questions.question: The day to day condition of the atmosphere at a place with respect to the temperature, humidity, rainfall, wind speed etc. is called _______ at that place.
questions.explanation: W eather . Climate - It is the long-term average of weather conditions, including temperature, humidity, precipitation, wind patterns, and other atmospheric elements, in a particular region over an extended period, typically 30 years or more. Q.494 . Which of the following pressure belts is known as the horse latitude? SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (2nd Shift) (a) Equatorial Low Pressure (b) Sub - Polar Low Pressure (c) High Pressure (d) Sub - Tropical High Pressure Sol.494.(d) Subtr opical high pr essur e belts (Horse latitude) extend 30° N and 30° S. It is formed because the warm air rising from the equator moves towards the tropics in both hemispheres. Equatorial Low - Pressure belt extends from 0 to 5° North and South. The subpolar low pressure belt extends around latitudes 60° to 70° North and South. High Pressure belts are located at 70°- 90° North and South latitudes. There are majorly seven Pressure Belts on the surface of Earth i.e., the Equatorial Low, two Subtropical Highs, two Subpolar Lows, and two Polar Highs.

questions.question: When the grains of sand are very ﬁne and light , the wind can carry it over a very long distance . When such sand is deposited in large areas, it is called_____.
questions.explanation: Loess. It is a clastic, predominantly silt-sized sediment that is formed by the accumulation of wind - blown dust.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the main reasons for the excessive cold in north India during the cold weather season and identify which of the statements are correct. 1. States like Punjab, Haryana and Rajasthan, being far away from the moderating in ﬂ uence of sea, experiencecontinental climate. 2. The snowfall in the nearby Himalayan ranges creates a cold wave situation. 3. Around February, the cold winds coming from the Caspian Sea and Turkmenistan bring a cold wave along with frost and fog over the northwestern parts of India.
questions.explanation: 1, 2 and 3. Coastal areas have moderate temperatures because the land absorbs and radiates heat much faster than sea. So, during the day cool air from the sea rushes towards the land and during the night cool air from the land rushes towards the sea.

questions.question: Low annual range of temperature and high annual rainfall are characteristics of a _________.
questions.explanation: T r opical Humid Climate: Low range of temperature, Rainfall exceeds evapotranspiration for at least 270 days in a year, between Tropic of Cancer and Capricorn.

questions.question: Which of the following codes signify the Cold Climate with Dry Winters according to Koeppen?
questions.explanation: Dw . Koeppen recognised six major climatic groups based on seasonal precipitation and temperature patterns. The six main groups are A (tropical), B (arid), C (temperate), D (continental), E (polar) and H (highland).

questions.question: The cold snow forest climate is found largely in the continental region in the Northern Hemisphere between _______ northern latitudes in Europe, Asia and North America
questions.explanation: 40°-70°. India has a tropical climate because of the Himalayan mountain.

questions.question: In early November, the low Pressure conditions shift over the Bay of Bengal. This transfer is related to cyclonic low pressure, which originates over ________.
questions.explanation: A ndaman Sea (Burma sea in Thai) is a body of water to the southeast of the Bay of Bengal, south of Myanmar, west of Thailand and east of the Andaman Islands; it is a part of the Indian Ocean.

questions.question: Which climate zone has an average temperature of over 64°F (18°C) throughout the year and more than 59 inches of rainfall each year?
questions.explanation: T r opical Z one. The tropics are regions of the Earth that lie roughly in the middle of the globe. The temperature remains high throughout the year. There is no marked winter season.

questions.question: What type of climate do the two island regions of India, Lakshadweep and Andaman and Nicobar Islands experience?
questions.explanation: T r opical warm climates with average temperatures ranging between 27° C - 32° C. Lakshadweep (an archipelago of 36 islands in the Arabian Sea). Hot semi-arid climate - Thar Desert.

questions.question: What type of precipitation is common at the equatorial depression in the Congo Basin, the Amazon Basin, and the islands of South-east Asia?
questions.explanation: Conv entional pr ecipitation occurs when the energy of the sun (or insolation) heats the earth's surface and causes water to evaporate, changing to water vapor. Most of India's rainfall is conventional. It is prevalent in equatorial regions. Orographic precipitation occurs when a topographic barrier like a mountain blocks the path of a movement of air horizontally. Frontal precipitation occurs along the zone of contact between a warm and cool air mass.

questions.question: ___is concerned with constructing records of past climates and climatic events by analysis of tree growthcharacteristics, especially growth rings.
questions.explanation: Dendr oclimat ology . Bioclimatology (biometeorology) is the study of the relationships between climate (weather) and living organisms. Historical climatology is the study of historical changes in climate and their effect on civilization from the emergence of hominids to the present day. Geo climatology is the study of climate which deﬁ nes how it changes over time.

questions.question: Select the INCORRECT statement from the following.

options.a: The development of the cotton textile industry in Britain led to the decline of Indian textile producers.
options.b: Cotton clothes made in England had driven Indian clothes out of the markets of Europe and America in the beginning of the 20th century.
options.c: The Sale and Devang communities of South India were famous for weaving.
options.d: The ﬁrst cotton textile mill in India was established in Bombay in 1854.

questions.explanation: By the beginning of the 20th century, India was not competing in European and American markets because British policies had already eliminated Indian textile exports to these regions by the 19th century. The decline of Indian textiles in international markets occurred much earlier, during the late 18th and 19th centuries, following the Industrial Revolution in Britain.

questions.question: Identify the oldest iron and steel company of India from the following options.
questions.explanation: T ata Ir on and Steel Company (TISCO) : Founded by Jamsetji Tata and Dorabji Tata in 1907, It is located in Jamshedpur (Jharkhand). Visvesvaraya Iron and Steel Plant: Founded in 1923, this plant is situated in Bhadravathi (Karnataka), and specializes in the production of pig iron and steel. Indian Iron and Steel Company (IISCO): Established in 1918, IISCO is anintegrated steel plant located in Burnpur (West Bengal) and is part of Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL).

questions.question: Identify the group of districts that are NOT an example of industrial districts of India.
questions.explanation: Alwar and Bhiwani. Cuttack (Odisha) is known for textile and handicraft industries, especially the silver ﬁligr ee (Tarakasi) work. Kota (Rajasthan) is famous for its engineering and chemical industries. Kanpur is a signi ﬁ cant industrial hub, historically known for its leather and textile industries. It is sometimes called the "Manchester of the East." Agra is widely known for its tourism, but it also has industries related to leather goods, footwear, and marble stone carving. Jabalpur (Madhya Pradesh) is known for ordnance factories, defense-related industries, and manufacturing units. Bhopal (Madhya Pradesh) is a major industrial center with industries like electrical goods, chemicals, and the famous Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited (BHEL).

questions.question: Which of the following is a public sector industry ?
questions.explanation: BHEL (Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited) was established in 1964 and is headquartered in New Delhi. Reliance Industries Limited is an Indian multinational company based in Mumbai, Maharashtra. It was founded by Dhirubhai Ambani. The Tata Group is one of India's oldest and largest business conglomerates. It was founded in 1868 by Jamsetji Tata. The Adani Group is an Indian multinational conglomerate based in Ahmedabad, Gujarat. It was founded in 1988 by Gautam Adani.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a major industrial region of India?
questions.explanation: Chota Nagpur r egion. India has several industrial regions like Mumbai- Pune cluster, Bangalore-Tamil Nadu region, Hugli region, Ahmedabad -Baroda region, Chottanagpur industrial belt, Vishakhapatnam-Guntur belt, Gurgaon -Delhi-Meerut region and the Kollam-Thiruvanathapuram industrial cluster.

questions.question: Where was the ﬁrst successful textile mill established in India?
questions.explanation: Mumbai. The ﬁrst successful textile mill in India was the Bombay Spinning and Weaving Company, established in 1854 in Bombay (now Mumbai) by Cowasjee Nanabhoy Davar, a Parsi businessman and banker. Located in Tardeo, Bombay, it began production in 1856.

questions.question: Where is the oldest centre of lace work located in Gujarat?
questions.explanation: Jamnagar . Crafts Centers of Gujarat : Kutch - Known for its rich tradition in embroidery and textile crafts. Surat - It is an important silk weaving center of India and is famous for silk brocades. Rajkot - It is popular for traditional and folk silver jewelry. Palitana - Known for making bronze sculptures. Ahmedabad (Manchester of India) - Famous for cotton textile works. The ﬁrst cott on textile mill was started in 1861.

questions.question: There is a cable manufacturing facility at HCL in Rupnarainpur. It belongs to which state?
questions.explanation: W est Bengal. West Bengal along with their notable industries: Durgapur (Iron and Steel), Kharagpur (Chemicals), Haldia (petrochemicals), Darjeeling (tea), Chittaranjan (Electric locomotives), Asansol (Coal, Iron and Steel), Kalyani (Heavy Engineering), Rishra (Textiles).

questions.question: According to the Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion, which of the following is NOT a core industry ?
questions.explanation: Jute. The eight core industries are- Coal, Crude oil, Natural Gas, Petroleum re ﬁ nery products,Fertilizer, Cement, Steel, and Electricity generation.

questions.question: Select the INCORRECT pair of the location of the re ﬁ nery and its state from the following

options.a: Bina Re ﬁ nery - Madhya Pradesh

questions.explanation: T atipaka Re ﬁ ner y - T elangana. Tatipaka Oil Re ﬁ nery is located in the East Godavari district in Andhra Pradesh. It was set up on 3rd September 2001. Some list of oil reﬁ neries: Vadinar Reﬁ nery (Gujarat), Kochi Re ﬁ nery (Kerala), Mangalore Reﬁ nery (Karnataka), Paradip Reﬁ nery (Odisha), Barauni Re ﬁ nery (Barauni in Bihar).

questions.question: Which group of states was concentrated in the cotton production in the early years to develop textile industry?
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a and Gujar at. Cotton is a tropical crop and it is raised in India as a Kharif crop. Climatic condition - Temperatures between 21 degrees Celsius and 30 degrees Celsius. It grows best in Black soil. India grows both short staple (Indian) cotton as well as long staple (American) cotton called ‘narma’ in north-western parts of the country.

questions.question: Where was the ﬁrst cement plant located in India in the year 1904 ?
questions.explanation: Chennai. South India Industries Limited in Madras, made an initiative to manufacture Portland cement. India entered into the Cement Era in 1914, when the Indian Cement Company Ltd. started manufacturing Cement in Porbandar in Gujarat.

questions.question: Which group of oil ﬁ elds among the following is located in Assam?
questions.explanation: Digboi and Naharkatiy a. Digboi Oil ﬁ eld : One of the oldest oil ﬁelds in Asia, discovered in 1867, and home to Asia's oldest oil re ﬁ nery (Established in 1901). It is located in Tinsukia district, Assam. Naharkatiya Oilﬁ eld : Discovered in 1953, with oil production starting in 1954. It is located in Dibrugarh district, Assam. Other Oil Reﬁ neries in Assam - Noonmati Reﬁ nery, Numaligarh Re ﬁ nery, and Bongaigaon Reﬁ nery. Kosamba, Lunej, Mehsana, Nawagam, Ankleshwar and Kalol are oil-producing regions located in Gujarat.

questions.question: Which of the following cities is called the Silicon Valley of India due to its prominence in the IT industry ?
questions.explanation: Bengaluru I. Nicknames of Indian Cities: Hyderabad - City of Pearls; Gurugram - Millennium City; Korba - Power Hub of India; Jamshedpur - Steel Capital of India; Nalanda - The Land of Knowledge; Guntur - Land of Chillies; Kashmir - Switzerland of India; Pondicherry - Paris of the East; Coimbatore - Manchester of South India; Chennai - Detroit of Asia.

questions.question: Which of the following is the only vertically-integrated, primary copper producer in India ?
questions.explanation: Hindustan Copper Limited . It is a public sector undertaking under the Ministry of Mines. The company was incorporated on 9th November 1967, under the Companies Act, 1956. Headquarters - Kolkata.

questions.question: At which of the following places was the shipbuilding industry started in 1941?
questions.explanation: Visakhapatnam. Hindustan Shipyard Limited (Visakhapatnam): It was set up by Scindia Steam Navigation Company and the ﬁrst ship was launched in 1948. It was taken over by the Government in 1952 and was renamed as Hindustan Shipyard Ltd. In 1962, the shipyard became a central public sector enterprise. Cochin Shipyard Limited (Kochi) - Incorporated in 1972 as a company fully owned by the Government.

questions.question: The Kolar region of Karnataka is famous for which mineral from the following ?
questions.explanation: Gold. Kolar - Golden City of India. It is popularly known as the land of Silk, Milk, Mango, Gold. Other Gold mines - Hutti Gold Mines (Karnataka), Kolar Gold Fields (Karnataka), Lava Gold Mines (Jharkhand), Sonbhadra Mine (Uttar Pradesh), Parasi (Jharkhand), Dadam (Haryana).

questions.question: Which state in India has the highest number of aluminium smelting plants?
questions.explanation: Odisha. Aluminum smelting plants - Korba, Alupuram, Renukoot, Mettur, Hirakud, Angul, Jharsuguda and Faridabad. Aluminium Companies in India - Hindustan Aluminium Company (Mumbai, Maharashtra), Vedanta Limited (Jharsuguda, Odisha), Sacheta Metals (Mumbai, Maharashtra).

questions.question: Which of the following industries is its own major consumer in India?
questions.explanation: Chemical. India is the 6th largest producer of chemicals in the world and 3rd in Asia. Also the fourth-largest producer of agrochemicals after the United States, Japan and China.

questions.question: Which city in India is known as the ‘Detroit of India’ due to its automobile industry?
questions.explanation: Chennai - It is contributing more than 40% of the country's auto parts and vehicles. The World's major automotive giants that operate in Chennai are TVS, Ashok Leyland, Royal Enﬁ eld, TI Cycle, TAFE, Hyundai, Mitsubishi etc.

questions.question: The Kudremukh Mines are located in which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Karnataka. Kudremukh Mines is an iron ore mine located in the Bellary, Chitradurga, Chikkamagaluru, Tumkur belt. Other Iron ore mines : Chhattisgarh - Rowghat Mines, Bailadila. Odisha - Balda Block, Joda East, Gorumahisani, Jajang Rungta. Madhya Pradesh - Agaria Iron Ore mine.

questions.question: In which of the following regions in India are there high-grade iron ore deposits?
questions.explanation: Nor thern Odisha. The iron ore mines are located near the coal ﬁelds in the northeastern plateau region. Odisha, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Karnataka, Goa, Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, and Tamil Nadu account for approximately 95% of total iron ore reserves. Iron Ore and Percentage of iron : Magnetite - 72 %, Hematite - 60-70 %, Limonite - 40 to 60%, Siderite - 48 %.

questions.question: Which is the ﬁrst integrated steel plant in the public sector in India?

options.a: The Visvesvaraya Iron and Steel Limited

questions.explanation: Rourk ela Steel Plant (Odisha - 1959 ). Established with the help of West German Industrial Corporations. Steel plants built in India during the Second Five Year Plan (FYP): Durgapur Steel Plant (West Bengal - Britain Cooperation), Bhilai Steel Plant (Chattisgarh - USSR Cooperation).

questions.question: Which is the oldest aluminium reﬁ nery plant in India?
questions.explanation: The Muri Alumina Plant - Situated near Chota Muri at Swarnarekha River in Ranchi (Jharkhand). It was commissioned in 1948. Its capacity is 450 Kilo tonne per annum (present). The Mettur Plant, Tamil Nadu. Damanjodi - Located in the Koraput district (Odisha), famous for discovery of bauxite mines and setting up of NALCO (National Aluminium Company Limited).Q.529. Which of the following is NOT an example of a minor industrial region of India? Matric Level 28/06/2023 (Shift - 4) (a) Ambala-Amritsar region (b) Durg-Raipur region (c) Hugli region (d) Northern Malabar region Sol.529.(c) Hugli r egion. Minor Industrial regions : Jaipur- Ajmer, Indore- Dewas- Ujjain, Saharanpur-Muzaffarnagar- Bijnor, Kolhapur- South Kannada, Middle Malabar, Adilabad - Nizamabad, Prayag- Varanasi- Mirzapur, Bhojpur- Munger, Bilaspur- Korba, Brahmaputra valley. Major Industrial Regions of India: Kolkata - Hugli, Mumbai - Pune Belt, Bengaluru - Tamil Nadu Belt, Kollam - Thiruvananthapuram Belt, Visakhapatnam - Guntur Belt, Chotanagpur Plateau Belt, Ahmedabad - Vadodara Belt, Gurugram - Delhi - Meerut Belt.

questions.question: Match the industrial plant with its location.Name of industrial PlantRelated Location 1. BALCO
