questions.explanation: BALCO (Bharat Aluminium Company Limited, 1965) has two working units, one in Korba (Chattisgarh) and one in Bidhanbag (West Bengal). ICF (Integral Coach Factory, 1955) is located in Perambur, Chennai, Tamil Nad.

questions.question: In the beginning of the 19th century cotton mills in India were mostly located in which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a. The ﬁrst cotton mill in India was set up as a spinning mill in Bombay in 1854. By 1900, over 84 mills (mostly by Parsi and Gujarati businessmen) started operating there.

questions.question: With respect to value addition in the textile industry, knitting is followed by which procedure?
questions.explanation: Dy eing and ﬁ nishing. In the textile industry, the process begins with ﬁber production, followed by spinning to create yarn, and then knitting or weaving to form fabric. Next comes dyeing, printing, and ﬁnishing to enhance the fabric, and ﬁnally , garment manufacturing, involving cutting and sewing. Thus, the step following knitting is dyeing and ﬁnishing.

questions.question: Which of the following is dark reddish coloured stone used as raw material in aluminum smelting?
questions.explanation: Bauxite.

questions.question: The Paithani saree weaving industry is in which state?
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a. They are woven by hand. They are made from very ﬁne mulberry silk.

questions.question: Imphal valley of Manipur is an important center of ________ craft.
questions.explanation: Kauna. Godna (Chattisgarh), Butta (Andhra Pradesh), and Miri Jims (Assam).

questions.question: Which is the second most important metallurgical industry in India?
questions.explanation: Aluminium (after the iron and steel industry). It is light, resistant to corrosion, a good conductor of heat, malleable, and becomes strong when it is mixed with other metals. It is used to manufacture aircraft, utensils, and wires.

questions.question: Match the following. 1. Ranthambore National Park
questions.explanation: 1-b, 2-c, 3-a.Q.538. In which state is Kawal Wildlife Sanctuary located ? SSC MTS 01/10/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Telangana (b) Gujarat (c) Odisha (d) Maharashtra Sol.538.(a) T elangana. Kawal Tiger Reserve is located at Adilabad district in Telangana. It was declared a wildlife sanctuary in 1965 and later became part of the Kawal Tiger Reserve under Project Tiger in 2012. Other wildlife sanctuaries in Telangana - Pranahita wildlife sanctuary, Shivaram wildlife Sanctuary, Nagarjuna Sagar-Srisailam Tiger Reserve, Kinnerasani, and Manjira Wildlife Sanctuary.

questions.question: The Betul, Hoshangabad and Chhindwara districts of Madhya Pradesh is a part of which of the following Biosphere Reserves?
questions.explanation: P achmarhi Biosphere Reserve is recognized for its rich biodiversity and has been designated as a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve in 2009. The Satpura mountain ranges across India from west to east and Pachmarhi lies directly in its centre. It comprises three protection sites: the Bori Sanctuary, Satpura National Park and Pachmarhi Sanctuary. Other Biosphere Reserve: Manas (Assam), Seshachalam (Andhra Pradesh), Agasthyamalai (Kerala and Tamil Nadu).

questions.question: As of the June 2021, how many biosphere reserves are established in India?
questions.explanation: 18. The Government of India started the Biosphere Reserve scheme in 1986. This is guided by the UNESCO MAB programme, as India is a signatory to the landscape approach supported by MAB. The Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve was theﬁrst and Oldest biosphere reserve in India established in 1986.

questions.question: Which national park in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands is home to species like Megapode, crab-eating Macaque, Nicobar Pigeon, and Giant Robber Crab?
questions.explanation: Campbell Ba y National P ark, established in 1992, spans 426.23 square km and is part of the Great Nicobar Biosphere Reserve. Other notable parks include Raimona National Park in Assam (famous for elephants and tigers), Mouling National Park in Arunachal Pradesh (known for temperate forests and Himalayan wildlife), and Papikonda National Park in Andhra Pradesh (noted for Eastern Ghats biodiversity).

questions.question: In which state of India is Tadoba National Park located?
questions.explanation: Mahar ashtr a. Tadoba National Park is located in the Chandrapur District. In 1955, it was given the designation of a National Park. Other National Parks of Maharashtra are Chandoli National Park, Navegaon National Park, Gugamal National Park, Sanjay Gandhi National Park.

questions.question: In which state is the Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve located?
questions.explanation: Uttar akhand. Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve included in UNESCO World Heritage site in 1988. Some biosphere reserves in India: Cold Desert (Himachal Pradesh), Khangchendzonga (Sikkim), Dihang - Dibang (Arunachal Pradesh), Manas (Assam), Dibru - Saikhowa (Assam), Nokrek (Meghalaya), Panna (Madhya Pradesh), Pachmarhi (Madhya Pradesh).

questions.question: Select the natural habitat of the Asiatic Lion from the following.
questions.explanation: Gir for est. Asiatic lions are an endangered species and their availability is restricted only to the Gir National Park situated in Gujarat. India is the only country in the world to have both tigers and lions. Tigers are found in the forests of Madhya Pradesh, the Sundarbans of West Bengal. Number of Lions in India - 674. The ﬁrst tiger reserve in India was established in 1973 (Project Tiger).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is/are correct I – Maximum National Parks in India are located in the state of Madhya Pradesh. II – Mudumalai National Park is located in Kerala. III – The Salim Ali Centre for Ornithology and Natural History is located in Tamil Nadu.

options.a: Both I and II are correct
options.b: Both I and III are correct

questions.explanation: Both I and III ar e corr ect.

questions.question: Which biosphere of Southern Andhra Pradesh is home to many endemic species including the famous Red Sanders and Slender Loris?
questions.explanation: Seshachalam. It is a Biosphere Reserve situated in the Seshachalam Hill ranges of the Eastern Ghats in southern Andhra Pradesh, covering a total area of 4755.9 km². Seshachalam SLBR was designated in 2011. It is known for its large reserves of Red Sandalwood.

questions.question: The Keoladeo National Park is located in the state of _______.
questions.explanation: Rajasthan. Keoladeo National Park in Bharatpur district was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985. States and National Parks: Rajasthan - Ranthambhore, Sariska. Gujarat - Gir, Marine. Odisha - Simlipal. Madhya Pradesh - Bandhavgarh, Fossil, Madhav, Sanjay-Dubri.

questions.question: Correctly match the following.States Bio-reserve 1. Assam a. Pachmarhi 2. Madhya Pradesh b. Nokrek 3. Odisha c. Manas 4. Meghalaya d. Similipa
Match the following.i) Gir National Park a) Rhinos ii) Rajaji National Parkb) Siberian cranes iii) Keoladeo NationalParkc) Lionsiv) Kaziranga National Parkd) Elephants
questions.explanation: i-c, ii-d, iii-b, iv-a. Jim Corbett National Park (Uttarakhand) - Tiger; Sundarban National Park (West Bengal) - Bengal tiger; Dudhwa National Park (Uttar Pradesh) - Swamp deer and Tiger; Silent Valley National Park (Kerala) - Lion Tailed Macaque; Orang National Park (Assam) - One Horned Rhinoceros and the Royal Bengal Tiger.

questions.question: Match the wildlife sanctuaries in column A with their corresponding states in column B. Column A (Wildlife Sanctuaries)Column B (States) 1. Tansa a. Tamil Nadu 2. Guindy b. Maharashtra 3. Orchha c. Madhya Pradesh 4. Kaziranga d. Assam
Which of the following is declared as a Wild Ass Sanctuary?
questions.explanation: Rann of Kachchh (Gujarat). It is the only home to wild ass in India. The sanctuary was set up in 1972.

questions.question: Which of the following is the closest wild relative of domestic cattle protected in some of the famous national parks of India like Nagarhole and Bandipur?
questions.explanation: Gaur . First population estimation exercise of the Indian Gaur (Bison) was carried out in the Nilgiris Forest Division (Tamil Nadu).

questions.question: In which Biosphere Reserve is the largest endangered marine mammal Dugong and sea turtles also found?
questions.explanation: Gulf of Mannar Biospher e Reser v e (Tamil Nadu, India’s ﬁrst marine biosphere reserve) .Biosphere Reserves-Seshachalam (Andhra Pradesh), Khangchendzonga (Sikkim), Pachmarhi (Madhya Pradesh).

questions.question: In which state is Gorumara National Park located?
questions.explanation: W est Bengal. Gorumara National Park was established in 1994. It is primarily known for its population of Indian rhinoceros. Other National Parks : West Bengal - Jaldapara, Sunderban, Singalila, Neora. Assam - Kaziranga, Nameri, Manas. Uttarakhand - Jim Corbett, Rajaji, Gangotri. Bihar - Valmiki. Rajasthan - Ranthambore, Keoladeo. Madhya Pradesh - Kanha, Van Vihar, Satpura.

questions.question: The famous Nelapattu Bird Sanctuary is located in which of the following states?
questions.explanation: A ndhr a Pr adesh. Nelapattu Bird Sanctuary - It is an important breeding site for spot-billed pelicans (Pelecanus philippensis). Other bird sanctuaries in Andhra Pradesh - Kolleru, Uppalapadu, Telineelapuram and Telukunchi. Tamil Nadu - Karikili Birds Sanctuary, Chitrangudi. Karnataka - Ranganathittu, Attiveri. Madhya Pradesh - Ghatigaon, Karera Bustard Sanctuary.

questions.question: Which country is the only country in the world to have both tigers and lions?
questions.explanation: India. The natural habitat of the Indian lion is the Gir forest in Gujarat. Tigers are found in the forests of Madhya Pradesh, the Sundarbans of West Bengal. Number of Lions in India - 674. In 2023, the tiger population in India was recorded at 3682.

questions.question: The Eld's deer subspecies, which is classi ﬁ ed as endangered in the IUCN Red List, is found only in the:

options.c: Keibul Lamjao National Park in Manipur
options.d: Pench National Park in Madhya Pradesh

questions.explanation: K eibul Lamjao National P ark in Manipur . IUCN Headquarter is at Gland, Switzerland. The 7 categories of the IUCN Red List are Data De ﬁ cient (DD), Least Concern (LC), Near Threatened (NT), Vulnerable (VU), Endangered (EN), Critically Endangered (CR), Extinct In The Wild (EW), Extinct (EX).

questions.question: The Buxa Tiger Reserve in West Bengal is threatened by the ongoing:
questions.explanation: Dolomite mining. Deforestation and large-scale developmental projects are the main reasons for the depletion of the Buxa Tiger Reserve.

questions.question: In which of the following states is the Srivilliputhur Elephant Reserve located?
questions.explanation: T amil Nadu. There are 33 Elephant Reserves in India. The very ﬁrst elephant reserve or elephant sanctuary was the Singhbhum Elephant Reserve of Jharkhand.

questions.question: Baghmara Pitcher Plant Sanctuary is located in which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Meghala y a (South Garo Hills District). The sanctuary is named after a rare insectivorous Pitcher Plant that is endemic to this region only.

questions.question: Laokhowa Wildlife Sanctuary lies on the southern bank of which river in the northeastern states of India ?
questions.explanation: Br ahmaputr a. Laokhowa Wildlife Sanctuary is protected area located in the state of Assam. This wildlife sanctuary covers 70.13 km2, on the south bank of the Brahmaputra River in Nagaon district.

questions.question: In which of the following Indian states is the Barnawapara Wildlife Sanctuary located?
questions.explanation: Chhattisgarh (Balodabazar district). It was established in 1976 under the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. The Jonk River ﬂows through the sanctuary, which is a tributary of the Mahanadi river.

questions.question: In which of the following states is Kali Tiger Reserve located ?
questions.explanation: Karnataka. Kali Tiger Reserve is a protected area and tiger reserve in Uttara Kannada district, in Karnataka. The park is a habitat of Bengal tigers, black panthers, and Indian elephants, amongst other distinctive fauna. The Kali River ﬂows through the whole tiger reserve.

questions.question: Peppara Wildlife Sanctuary is situated in which of the following states ?
questions.explanation: K er ala. Other Wildlife Sanctuaries in Kerala : Eravikulam, Periyar, Shendurney, Chinnar, Parambikulam, Idukki, Wayanad, Thattekad.

questions.question: Dandeli Wildlife Sanctuary is located in which of the following states?
questions.explanation: Karnataka.

questions.question: The wetland of Ashtamudi is located in:
questions.explanation: K er ala (in Kollam District). It has a unique wetland ecosystem and a large palm shaped waterbody. Ashtamudi Wetland is included in the list of wetlands of international importance.

questions.question: Which sanctuary is famous for endangered Estuarine Crocodiles conservation in India?
questions.explanation: Bhitarkanika Wildlif e Sanctuar y (Odisha) is a Ramsar site and is one of India’s biggest estuarine crocodile habitats and a major coastal ecosystem.Q.568. Which wildlife sanctuary is a tri-state protected area in northern India? It is also famous for the Critically Endangered gharial, the red-crowned roofed turtle and the Endangered Ganges river dolphin? SSC CHSL 20/10/2020(Afternoon) (a) National Chambal Sanctuary (b) Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary (c) Dandeli Wildlife Sanctuary (d) Bhadra Wildlife Sanctuary Sol.568.(a) National Chambal Sanctuar y is located on the Chambal River near the tri-point of Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: In which district of Karnataka is the Brahmagiri Wildlife Sanctuary located?
questions.explanation: K odagu (Coorg). Brahmagiri Wildlife Sanctuary is situated on the border between Wayanad District of Kerala state on the south and Kodagu District in Karnataka on the north side.

questions.question: Which National Park among the following is the largest protected area in the Eastern Himalayan sub-region?
questions.explanation: Namdapha National P ark (Arunachal Pradesh). It has more than 1,000 ﬂor al and about 1,400 faunal species. It is a biodiversity hotspot in the Eastern Himalayas.

questions.question: Select the correct order of the following plateaus and ranges from south to north in India.

options.a: Malwa Plateau, Vindhya Range, Satpura Range and Deccan Plateau
options.b: Deccan Plateau, Vindhya Range, Satpura Range and Malwa Plateau
options.c: Deccan Plateau, Satpura Range, Vindhya Range and Malwa Plateau
options.d: Malwa Plateau, Satpura Range, Vindhya Range and Deccan Plateau

questions.explanation: Deccan Plateau: The southernmost plateau, covering parts of Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, and Telangana. Satpura Range: Located to the north of the Deccan Plateau and runs through Madhya Pradesh and Maharashtra. Vindhya Range: Lies further north of the Satpura Range, stretching across Madhya Pradesh and separating the northern plains from the southern plateaus. Malwa Plateau: Located to the north of the Vindhya Range, covering parts of Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan.

questions.question: In which of the following types of regions, is the maximum temperature variation observed between a day and the same night?
questions.explanation: Deser t like the ‘Thar Desert’ experience extreme temperature variations due to low moisture, sparse vegetation, and clear skies. Daytime temperatures can reach up to 50°C, while nights drop to around 15°C, creating a difference of about 35°C in 24 hours.

questions.question: Which physical feature of India prevents the cold winds from central Asia from entering the Indian subcontinent?
questions.explanation: Himala y a : It acts as a natural barrier, blocking cold winds from Central Asia and protecting the climate of India. This mountain range effectively protects the subcontinent, and maintains its relatively warm temperatures. Coastal area : Allows winds from the sea to enter India.

questions.question: In which of the following districts of Rajasthan are the ‘Barchans’ found?
questions.explanation: Jaisalmer . Barchan, crescent-shaped sand dune produced by the action of wind predominately from one direction. The Indian desert lies west of the Aravali Hills, with sandy plains and sand dunes. It receives very low rainfall (below 150 mm annually) and has an arid climate with sparse vegetation.

questions.question: Purvanchal Himalayas does NOT comprise of :
questions.explanation: Pir P anjal Range in the Himalayas is a part of the Lesser Himalayas. The Pir Panjal Range starts near PatniTop in Jammu and Kashmir and runs through Himachal Pradesh toGarhwal. The Purvanchal Himalayas, also known as the Eastern Hills, are a mountain range in northeastern India. This range includes the Patkai Hills, the Naga Hills in Nagaland, the Manipur Hills in Manipur, and the Mizo Hills in Mizoram.

questions.question: Which of the following hills is located in the Eastern Ghats?
questions.explanation: She v ar o y hills. The Eastern Ghats are a series of discontinuous low hills with an average elevation of 600 meters. They extend parallel to the east coast, from the southern part of the Mahanadi valley to the Nilgiri hills. The highest peak in this region is Jindhagada Peak (1,690 meters). Notable hills in the Eastern Ghats include : Mahendragiri and Niyamgiri hills in Odisha, Nallamala hills (Andhra Pradesh), and Kollimalai and Pachaimalai hills in Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: In the southern ranges of which hills is Mawsynram, which receives the highest rainfall in the world, located?
questions.explanation: Khasi hills: These are part of the Meghalaya subtropical forests ecoregion and, along with the Garo and Jaintia Hills, contribute to the state of Meghalaya, meaning "abode of the clouds" in Sanskrit. Mawsynram, located about 16 kilometers west of Cherrapunji, is recognized as the wettest place on Earth, receiving a higher annual average rainfall than Cherrapunji.

questions.question: What is the name of the highest peak of the Eastern Ghats?
questions.explanation: Mahendr agir . This hill was once believed to be the highest peak in the Eastern Ghats. However, in April 2011, a team led by Mr. Venkat Reddy Y found that the elevation of Mahendra Giri Hill is actually 1,501 meters. Jindhagada Peak: After this discovery, it was determined that the highest peak in the Eastern Ghats is Jindhagada Peak, which stands at 1,690 meters. It is located in the Araku Valley in Andhra Pradesh.

questions.question: Which sub-division of Himalayas are famous for Karewa formations ?
questions.explanation: Kashmir Himala y as. Karewa - thick deposits of glacial clay and moraines. These are the ﬂat topped mounds that border the Kashmir Valley on all sides. The other Himalayan sub-divisions are: Uttarakhand Himalayas: Between the Ravi and Kali rivers. Arunachal Himalayas: Between the Tista and Brahmaputra rivers. Sikkim Himalayas: Between the Kali and Teesta rivers.

questions.question: The Lushai Hills are also known as _________.
questions.explanation: Miz o Hills (Mizoram and Manipur). The highest point of Mizo hills is the Blue Mountain. Eastern Hills (The Purvanchal) are the southward extension of Himalayas running along the north-eastern edge of India.

questions.question: The central stretch of the Western Coastal Plains of India is known as the:
questions.explanation: Kannad plains (Between Goa and Mangalore) .Malabar coast - Extends from the southern part of Goa to Kanyakumari.

questions.question: The Himalayas' outermost range is called __________.
questions.explanation: Shiwaliks. They extend over a width of 10-50 Km and have an altitude varying between 900 and 1100 metres. They have low hills like Jammu Hills, etc. Pir Panjal and Dhauladhar are important ranges of lesser Himalayas.

questions.question: In which direction is the general elevation of the peninsular plateau of India?
questions.explanation: F r om W est t o East. The Peninsular Plateau of India lies south of the Northern Plains, with an average elevation of 600-900 m. It consists of smaller plateaus and hill ranges with river basins and valleys. The plateau is divided into three groups: Central Highlands (e.g., Malwa, Bundelkhand), Deccan Plateau (e.g., Maharashtra, Karnataka), and Northwestern Plateau (e.g., Aravalli, Vindhya, Satpura ranges).

questions.question: Which of the following hills is located in the Eastern most part of India?
questions.explanation: P atkai Bum Hills. Patkai Hills (Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland and Upper Burma region of Myanmar). Western Ghats {Anamudi (highest peak), Mannamala, Meesapulimala, Doddabetta peak, Kolaribetta Peak, etc). The Mizo Hills, located in the southeastern Mizoram state, were formerly called Lushai Hills.

questions.question: What is the average elevation of the Eastern Ghats of India?
questions.explanation: 600 metr es. Eastern Ghats comprises the discontinuous and low hills that are highly eroded by the rivers such as the Mahanadi, the Godavari, the Krishna, the Cauvery, etc. The Eastern Ghats are a mesmerising mountain range that extends across the states of Odisha, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Karnataka, and Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Choose the correct statements about the islands of India. a. Lakshadweep Islands are composed of coral islands. b. Andaman and Nicobar islands are composed of coral islands. c. It is believed that Lakshadweep islands are an elevated portion of submarine mountains. d. It is believed that Andaman and Nicobar islands are an elevated portion of submarine mountains.
questions.explanation: a and d.

questions.question: What is the name of the physical feature that is the longitudinal valley lying between the Lesser Himalayas and the Siwalik in India?
questions.explanation: Duns are structurally formed valleys covered with boulders and gravelfrom the erosion of the Himalayas and Shivalik uplands. Major duns in the region include Dehra, Kohtri, Chaukham, Patli, and Kota, with Dehradun being the largest at 35 km long and 25 km wide.

questions.question: The Himalayas have uplifted from which of the following geosynclines?
questions.explanation: T ethys geosynclines. The northward drift of the Indian Plate resulted in the collision of the plate with the much larger Eurasian Plate. Due to this collision, the sedimentary rocks which were accumulated in the geosyncline known as the Tethys were folded to form the mountain system of western Asia and Himalaya.

questions.question: What is the name of the northern part of the western coastal plain between Mumbai and Goa?
questions.explanation: K onkan coast. The central stretch of Arabian Sea is called the Kannad Plain, while the southern stretch is known as the Malabar coast. In the Bay of Bengal, the northern part is called the Northern Circar, and the southern part is the Coromandel Coast.

questions.question: Which of the following physiographic divisions of India has extensive alluvial soil ?
questions.explanation: The Nor th Indian Plain is formed by alluvial deposits brought by rivers such as the Indus, Ganga, and Brahmaputra. These plains stretch about 3,200 km from east to west and are divided into three zones: Bhabar, Tarai, and Alluvial plains. Bhabar is a narrow belt near the Shiwalik foothills, while Tarai lies south of it. The alluvial plains include the Khadar (new alluvium) and Bhangar (old alluvium).

questions.question: The Great Indian desert/Thar desert is located on the western margin of which of the following mountain ranges?
questions.explanation: Ar a v alli r ange. It runs approximately 670 km (430 mi) in a south-west direction, starting near Delhi, passing through southern Haryana and Rajasthan, and ending in Gujarat. The highest peak is Guru Shikhar at 1,722 metres (5,650 ft). Vindhya range forms a dividing line between the Ganges Plain and the Deccan Plateau. Satpura range is situated between two west ﬂowing rivers - Narmada and Tapi.

questions.question: Choose the correct statements about the Western Ghats. a. The height of the Western Ghats progressively increases from north to south. b. Mahendragiri is the highest peak in the Western Ghats. c. The Western Ghats are higher than the Eastern Ghats. d. The height of the Western Ghats progressively decreases from north to south.
questions.explanation: a and c. The highest peak in the Western Ghats is Anamudi (2,695 metres).

questions.question: Which triangular plateau region of India lies south of the river Narmada?
questions.explanation: Deccan plateau. Its broad base is ﬂank ed by the Satpura Range to the north, while the Mahadev, Kaimur Hills, and Maikal Range extend to the east. The Deccan Plateau is higher in the west and slopes gently eastwards.

questions.question: Geologically, which of the following physiographic divisions of India is supposed to be one of the most stable land blocks?
questions.source: Graduate Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 3) a) The Northern Plains (b) The Himalayas (c) The Peninsular Plateau (d) The Indian Desert
questions.explanation: The P eninsular plateau is a tableland composed of the old crystalline, igneous and metamorphic rocks. This plateau consists of two broad divisions, namely, the Central Highlands and the Deccan Plateau. The part of the Peninsular plateau lying to the north of the Narmada river. The Indian desert lies towards the western margins of the Aravali Hills. It is an undulating sandy plain covered with sand dunes. The northern plain is formed of alluvial soil. The Himalayas, geologically young and structurally fold mountains stretch over the northern borders of India.

questions.question: With reference to the physical features of India, the ‘Kayals’ are _________.
questions.explanation: Backwaters: The inland water bodies, often formed by the merging of rivers and lakes or by the back ﬂ ow of seawater, creating a network of interconnected waterways. In Kerala, these backwaters are locally known as kayals.

questions.question: Which of the following physical divisions of India is densely populated?
questions.explanation: The Nor th Indian Plains has been formed by the interplay of the three major river systems, namely the Indus, the Ganga and the Brahmaputra along with their tributaries, which makes its soil highly fertile. Alluvial soil is the major soil found in the plains. The swampy belt of the plains is known as terai.

questions.question: India accounts for what percent of the total geographical area of the world ?
questions.explanation: 2.4 %. The land mass of India has an area of 3.28 million square km. India is the seventh largest country in the world. Largest countries in the world: Russia, Canada, China, United States, Brazil, Australia, etc.

questions.question: The Standard Meridian of India (82°30’E) passes through _______ state of India.
questions.explanation: Madhy a Pr adesh. The Standard Meridian - A longitude that determines a standard time for the whole country.

questions.question: Which of the following Indian states is biggest in terms of area?
questions.explanation: Rajasthan. Indian states biggest in terms of area: Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat. Smallest state (in terms of area) - Goa. Smallest Union Territories (in terms of area) - Lakshadweep, Daman and Diu, Chandigarh, Puducherry, Dadra and Nagar Haveli, Delhi.

questions.question: India's total length of coastline of the mainland including Andaman and Nicobar and Lakshadweep is ________
questions.explanation: 7516.6 km. Length of Coastline of the Indian mainland - 6100 km. The Coast of the Indian mainland is surrounded by Arabian Sea in the west, Bay of Bengal in the east , and Indian Ocean in the south. India's coastline extends to Nine states (Gujarat, Maharashtra, Goa, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh, Odisha, and West Bengal). Largest coastline - Gujarat (1214 km).

questions.question: The plains from Ambala to the Sunderban stretch over nearly 1800 km, but the fall in its slope is hardly ________ metres.
questions.explanation: 300 . In other words, there is a fall of just one meter for every 6 km. Therefore, the river develops large meanders. Ambala is located on the water divide between the Indus and the Ganga river systems.

questions.question: When the river approaches sea it breaks up into a number of distributaries, each distributary forms its own mouth. The collection of sediments from all the mouths forms _______.
questions.explanation: Delta. Meander is a pronounced curve or loop in the course of a river channel. Floodplains are an area of low-lying ground adjacent to a river, formed mainly by ﬂooding of rivers and the deposition of sand sediments on the riverbanks.

questions.question: Devka Beach, a beautiful expanse of black sand is located in______
questions.explanation: Daman. Radhanagar Beach (Havelock Island, Andaman). Juhu Beach, Mumbai. Ramakrishna Beach (Andhra Pradesh), Candolim Beach (Goa). Marina beach (Chennai) is India's longest and the world's second longest beach. Puri Beach (Golden beach), Odisha.

questions.question: Which of the following factors are responsible for railways having not developed much in the north-eastern parts of India? (1) Highly dissected topography (2) Dense forests (3) Low population density (4) Heavy rainfall and frequent ﬂooding
questions.explanation: 1,2 and 4. The northeastern part of India is marked by the presence of big rivers, dissected relief, dense forests, frequent ﬂoods, landslides, international frontiers, etc. The ﬁrst r ailway proposals for India were made in Madras in 1832. As a result, the country got its ﬁrst train in the form of the Red Hill Railway which was built with the sole purpose of transporting granite for road-building in 1837.

questions.question: Which of the following is a mountain pass in the Pir Panjal range at a maximum altitude of 2832 meters that connects the Kashmir Valley in the Union Territory of Jammu and Kashmir with the Outer Himalayas and the plains in the south?
questions.explanation: Banihal pass (Jammu and Kashmir) is situated in the Pir - Panjal Range. It connects Banihal with Qazigund. Mana Pass (Uttarakhand) is located in the Greater Himalayas and connects Tibet with Uttarakhand. Bara lacha pass - Connects Himachal Pradesh's Lahaul area with Ladakh. Zojila Pass connects Leh and Srinagar.

questions.question: With reference to the major regions of the northern plains, Bhabar is:

options.a: the older alluvium along the river beds forming terraces higher than the ﬂoodplain
options.b: a narrow belt of about 8 to 16 km that runs in the west-east direction along the foot of the Himalayas from the river Indus to Teesta
options.c: composed of newer alluvium and forms ﬂood plains along the river banks
options.d: a broad long zone of northern India and southern Nepal running parallel to the lower ranges of the Himalayas

questions.explanation: Bhabar is a narrow belt lying parallel to the slopes of the Shiwaliks in Uttarakhand. It is narrow in the east and wide in the western and northwestern hilly regions. It comprises gravel and un-assorted sediment deposits. Crop cultivation is not possible in this tract, only giant trees with deep roots grow.

questions.question: In which of the following regions of India is the natural habitat of White-bellied Heron largely distributed?
questions.explanation: Nor th-east India, the easternmost region of the country, comprises eight states: Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, Manipur, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, Tripura, and Sikkim.

questions.question: Deserts, rain,forests, coral reefs, and mangroves are features of ________ diversity.
questions.explanation: E cological diversity includes species diversity, genetic diversity, and ecosystem diversity. They are collectively considered biodiversity. It is the sum of all kinds of animals and plants living on this earth along with their habitat.

questions.question: Which of the following is a district-cum-tourism hotspot of Arunachal Pradesh?
questions.explanation: T awang. Kalimpong, Alipurduar, and Jalpaiguri are the districts in West Bengal.

questions.question: The archaeological site of Atranjikhera is located in _______.
questions.explanation: Uttar Pr adesh. This site was ﬁrst identiﬁ ed by Sir Alexander Cunningham in 1862 but excavated by R C Gaur in 1962.

questions.question: In the state of ______, the general direction of the Himalayas is from southwest to northeast.
questions.explanation: Arunachal Pr adesh. Himalayas in the Darjeeling and Sikkim regions lie in an east-west direction.

questions.question: Which of the following mountain is situated in the state of Uttarakhand?
questions.explanation: Mangsha Dhur a P ass. Other passes in Uttarakhand: Kalindi Pass, Lipulekh Pass, Mana Pass, Auden's Col, Muling La, Nama Pass, Niti Pass, Traill's Pass.

questions.question: Which among the following states does NOT share its border with Odisha?
questions.explanation: Bihar . Odisha is surrounded by 4 states: Andhra Pradesh from the south, Chhattisgarh from the west and Jharkhand and West Bengal from the north.

questions.question: River Sutlej enters India through which pass?
questions.explanation: Shipki La - From here, Satluj traverses through many Himalayan valleys before it merges with Chenab in Pakistan before landing into Indus.

questions.question: Which among the following is a western coast island?
questions.explanation: Elephanta island is located in Mumbai Harbour of the Arabian Sea. Pamban (between peninsular India and Sri Lanka), Parikud (Odisha), and Sriharikota (Andhra Pradesh).

questions.question: What is the length of the Indian Railways network, according to the Railway Yearbook 2019-20 ?
questions.explanation: 67,956 km. The length of the Indian Railways network, according to the Railway Yearbook 2019-20 : Broad gauge - The distance between the rails is 1.676 meters, with a total length of 63,950 km. Metre gauge - The distance between the rails is 1 meter, with a total length of 2,402 km. Narrow gauge - The distance between the rails is either 0.762 meters or 0.610 meters, with a total length of 1,604 km.

questions.question: According to the Indian Railways (2019-2020), which state has the largest railway track in India?
questions.explanation: Uttar Pr adesh. The longest railway track in India is the Dibrugarh-Kanyakumari Vivek Express (approx 4200 km), running from Dibrugarh in Assam to Kanyakumari in Tamil Nadu. The shortest railway line is the 3-kilometer route between Nagpur and Ajni in Maharashtra. The ﬁv e states with the largest route kilometers are Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, Maharashtra, Gujarat, and Andhra Pradesh.

questions.question: In which of the following states is the development of rail transport less, due to its geographical conditions?
questions.source: SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (3rd Shift) (a) Sikkim (b) Haryana (b) Bihar (d) Uttar Pradesh
questions.explanation: Sikkim is predominantly mountainous, characterized by steep slopes and rugged terrain, which complicates the construction of rail infrastructure.

questions.question: Through which routes is the majority of India’s international trade carried out?
questions.explanation: Sea and air . India has a coastline of approximately 7,516.6 km, making maritime transport essential for international trade. According to the Ministry of Shipping, about 95% of India's trade by volume and 70% by value is conducted via sea routes. A smaller portion of trade occurs through land routes to neighboring countries, including Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, and Pakistan.

questions.question: According to the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways’ annual report (2020-2021), which position does India have in terms of road networks in the world?
questions.explanation: Second. India has the second largest road network in the world after the USA. India’s road network stands at over 63,71,847 km. This comprises National Highways, Expressways, State Highways, Major District Roads, other District Roads and Village Roads (Ministry of Road Transport & Highways Annual Report FY 2021-22). Q.621 . As of Financial year 2019, which of the following states has the highest road density in India? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Haryana (b) Tamil Nadu (c) Kerala (d) Punjab Sol.621.(c) K er ala. As of the ﬁnancial y ear 2019, Kerala had the highest road density among states, with 6.7 thousand kilometers of roads per one thousand square kilometers. Among union territories, Chandigarh had the highest road density in India, with over 22.6 thousand kilometers per one thousand square kilometers. Road density refers to the total length of all roads in a country, including highways, national roads, and city or rural roads, compared to the country's land area.

questions.question: By which National Waterways (NW) of India, are the delta channels of Mahanadi and Brahmani rivers and East Coast Canal connected?
questions.explanation: NW 5. It connects the states of Odisha and West Bengal, stretching 623 km in total, with 91 km in West Bengal and 532 km in Odisha. National Waterway-1 (NW-1) spans the Ganga-Bhagirathi-Hooghly river system from Prayagraj, Uttar Pradesh, to Haldia, West Bengal. National Waterway-2 covers 891 km of the Brahmaputra River between the Bangladesh border near Dhubri and Sadiya in Assam. National Waterway-3, also known as the West Coast Canal, is a 168 km route in Kerala from Kollam to Kottapuram.

questions.question: About what percentage of passenger tra ﬃ c is carried by roads in India?
questions.explanation: 87%. The Road Transport Sector handles about 60% of freight traﬃ c in India. For passenger traﬃ c, roads account for 87%, railways for 12%,and both air and waterways contribute approximately 0.5% each, as per the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an eastern coast port?
questions.explanation: Chennai P or t started its commercial operations in 1881. The major ports on the eastern coast : Tuticorin - Tamil Nadu, Ennore - Tamil Nadu, Chennai - Tamil Nadu, Haldia and Kolkata - West Bengal, Paradip - Odisha, Visakhapatnam - Andhra Pradesh, Port Blair - Andaman and Nicobar Islands.

questions.question: Which of the following ports was developed as a Satellite port to relieve the pressure at the Mumbai port?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru P or t (Nhava Sheva), established on 26 May 1989, is India's second-largest container port, following Mundra Port. New Mangalore Port, in Karnataka, is operated by the New Mangalore Port Trust. Mormugao Port, commissioned in 1885, is located on Goa's western coast.

questions.question: In which year was the Konkan Railway constructed?
questions.explanation: 1998. Indian Railways founded the Konkan Railway on 19th July 1990. Konkan Railways crosses 146 river streams, nearly 2000 bridges, and 91 tunnels. The states of Maharashtra, Goa, and Karnataka are partners in this undertaking.

questions.question: The Atal Tunnel has been built by Border Road Organisation at an altitude of 3000 metres. Which places are connected by this tunnel?
questions.explanation: Manali t o Lahaul-Spiti. questions.question: When was air transport nationalised in India?
questions.explanation: 1953. The Air Corporations Act of 1953 led to the nationalization of Indian airlines and the formation of two corporations: Indian Airlines for domestic routes and Air India International for international routes.

It was renamed Rabindra Setu in 1965 after the great Bengali poet Rabindranath Tagore. But it is still popularly known by the name Howrah Bridge.

questions.question: What is the total length of the Golden Quadrilateral, built by the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI)?

The routes are Delhi-Kolkata via NH-2, Mumbai-Delhi via NH-8, Mumbai-Chennai via NH-4, and Chennai-Kolkata via NH-5. The National Highways Authority of India, established in 1988, operates under the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways.

questions.question: The historical Sher Shah Suri Marg is called the National Highway no. _________ between Delhi and Amritsar.
questions.explanation: 1. Sher Shah Suri built the Shahi (Royal) Road to strengthen and consolidate his empire from the Indus Valley to Bengal's Sonar Valley. This road was renamed the Grand Trunk (GT) Road during British rule, connecting Kolkata and Peshawar. Currently, it extends from Amritsar to Kolkata and is divided into two segments: National Highway (NH)-1 from Delhi to Amritsar and NH-2 from Delhi to Kolkata.

questions.question: In which of the following years was the air transport in India launched?
questions.explanation: 1911. Air Transportation: Air transport in India was launched between Allahabad and Naini (10 km). George Light started Air Transport in India. questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a part of the six communication mail channels in India?

questions.question: How many phases are involved in the census operations in India?
questions.explanation: T wo. First - Houselisting/Housing Census under which details of all buildings, permanent or temporary, are noted with their type, amenities, and assets. Second - Population Enumeration where more detailed information on each individual residing in the country, Indian national or otherwise is noted. The ﬁrst non-synchr onous census was conducted in 1872 under Lord Mayo's administration, while the ﬁrst synchr onous census took place in 1881 under W.C. Plowden. questions.question: As per the de ﬁ nition of Census of India, a ‘marginal worker’ is a person who works for:

options.a: less than 183 days (or six months) in a year
options.b: more than 183 days (or six months) in a year

questions.explanation: The population of India according to their economic status is divided into three groups, namely; main workers, marginal workers and non-workers. A Main Worker is a person who works for at least 183 days (or six months) in a year. Marginal Worker is a person who works for less than 183 days (or six months) in a year. The proportion of workers (both main and marginal) is only 39.8 per cent (2011) leaving a vast majority of about 60 percent as non-workers.

questions.question: The Accelerated Female Literacy Programme was initiated in districts where the female literacy rate, based on the 2001 census, was _______.
questions.explanation: below 30%. According to the 2001 Census, 47 districts in India had a female literacy rate below 30%. Most of these districts were located in Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, and Odisha. The Accelerated Female Literacy Programme aims to empower women by helping them develop literacy skills and gain access to information and services.

questions.question: According to Census of India 2011, what is the gap between male and female literacy rate in India?

Literacy rates for States and Union Territories (UTs) : Kerala - 94% (highest among states), Bihar - 61.80% (lowest among states), Lakshadweep - 91.85% (highest among UTs), Dadra and Nagar Haveli - 76.24% (lowest among UTs), Mizoram - 91.33%, Goa - 88.70% and Delhi - 86.21%.

questions.question: According to Census 2011, which district displays the highest population?

questions.question: Who published the logistic equation model of population growth in 1838 ?
questions.explanation: Pierr e F r ançois V erhulst. He was a Belgian mathematician who earned a doctorate in number theory from the University of Ghent in 1825. He is renowned for the logistic growth model, which is widely applied in population growth modeling. This model, ﬁrst proposed by Pierre-François Verhulst in 1838, states that the reproduction rate is proportional to both the existing population and the available resources, assuming all else is equal.

questions.question: According to the Census of India 2011, which group of Union Territories has the highest density of population?

questions.question: What was India's annual exponential growth rate as per the 2011 Census?

questions.question: The growth rate of India's population has been declining since ____.
questions.explanation: 1981. The pace of population growth is slowing down in the country. Two major reasons behind this decline: a decrease in the fertility rate and improvements in family planning practices. The population growth rate was 23.6% in the decade 1981-1991, which declined to 21.5% in 1991-2001. This rate declined further to 17.6% in the decade 2001-2011.

questions.question: After independence, the Census Act was enacted in India in the year __________.

questions.question: Atmospheric temperature usually decreases with altitude, but sometimes this phenomenon gets reversed in the troposphere. This phenomenon is known as _________.

questions.question: What kind of radiation is absorbed by the ozone layer?

This layer acts as a shield, protecting the Earth from the Sun's harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation. Infrared radiation (IR), also known as thermal radiation, is that band in the electromagnetic radiation spectrum with wavelengths above red visible light between 780 nm to 1mm (0.78 μm to 1000 μm).

questions.question: A dense mass of water drops on smoke or dust particles in the lower atmosphere layers is referred to as:

It is essentially a cloud at or near the ground, leading to poor visibility, often reduced to zero. Fog is denser and thicker than mist. Fog reduces visibility to less than one kilometer, while mist reduces visibility to one to two kilometers. Frost forms on cold surfaces when condensation takes place below freezing point (00C), i.e. the dew point is at or below the freezing point. Q.758 . The upper portion of the earth is known as: SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift) (a) Stratosphere (b) Troposphere (c) Lithosphere (d) Mesosphere Sol.758.(c) Lithospher e. It is bounded by the atmosphere above and the asthenosphere (another part of the upper mantle) below. The stratosphere is the second-lowest layer of Earth's atmosphere. The troposphere, the lowest layer of the atmosphere, contains about 75-80% of the atmospheric mass. Most clouds form in the troposphere, where nearly all weather occurs. The mesosphere is the third highest layer, situated between the stratosphere and the thermosphere.

questions.question: The zone separating the troposphere from the stratosphere is called the __________.

The temperature in this region is nearly constant, and hence, it is called the tropopause. The stratosphere is found above the tropopause and extends up to a height of 50 km. One important feature of the stratosphere is that it contains the ozone layer.

questions.question: All the changes in climate and weather takes place in _________ .
questions.explanation: T r opospher e. It is the lowermost layer of the atmosphere and is often referred to as the "region of mixing”. Its average height is 13 km and extends roughly to a height of 8 km near the poles and about 18 km at the equator. Stratosphere (contains the ozone layer) - 2nd layer of the Earth's atmosphere, extending from about 10 to 50 km in altitude. Mesosphere - 3rdlayer of the Earth's atmosphere, extending from about 50 to 85 km in altitude. Most meteors burn up in this atmospheric layer. Thermosphere - 4thlayer of the Earth's atmosphere, extending from about 85 to 500 km in altitude.
